column1: Mission Description

Active Minds @ Harvard/CAMHS, is a peer education group under the umbrella of Harvard University Health Services (HUHS) that acts as liaisons between Counseling and Mental Health Services (CAMHS) and the Harvard College community. We work collaboratively with CAMHS, the Harvard administration, and student communities to promote awareness of issues and improve accessibility to resources related to mental health and wellness. In an effort to do so, we strive to reduce stigma surrounding mental health and engage in outreach to address the specific needs of various communities on campus. We strive to encourage open conversation about matters of mental health and educate students about resources on campus. Ultimately, we hope to help the community to better understand issues of emotional well-being, recognize signs of students in distress, and feel comfortable navigating resources for support.

Advocating Success for Kids (ASK) is a primary care clinic at Boston Children’s Hospital designed for children with behavioral and learning disabilities. Our ASK club aligns with this clinic; members serve as advocates for patient families. Our mission is to support the ASK clinic and its patients through advocacy work. Harvard undergraduates serve as Advocates. They not only have the opportunity to shadow physicians in the ASK Clinic, but also serve patient families as well. Advocates provides a great deal of support to families including access to social and educational resources and an alternative line of communication to the Clinic. Advocates fill a key gap in the healthcare services that families of the ASK Clinic receive.
An Evening with Champions is a public charity non-profit committee dedicated to fighting cancer by raising money for The Jimmy Fund, the fundraising arm of Dana-Farber Cancer Institute.

We are ApiChorus, Harvard Hillel's Premier Jewish Student A Cappella Group. Founded in 2023, ApiChorus is a coed group comprised of current undergraduate students at Harvard College. We sing a diverse repertoire of Hebrew and English classics, represent a broad range of Jewish backgrounds, and perform at venues locally in Cambridge as well as in concerts across the country.
Promoting the appreciation and understanding of Armenian history, heritage and culture at Harvard College.

We, the brothers of the Asian American Brotherhood, have united ourselves in order to forge a stronger sense of unity among Asian Americans in our community and to foster solidarity without coercion. In promoting understanding and bonds across ethnic lines, the Asian American Brotherhood seeks to empower both our members and the communities that we serve.

ABSK is concerned with the religious, social, and cultural issues regarding Christianity and Asians and Christianity. The group will seek to promote greater awareness and understanding of these issues in the Harvard community by appropriate means such as Bible studies, publications, meetings, seminars, and other educational activities.

The purpose of ASAP is to provide the network and resources for Pan-Asian and Pan-Asian-American students across multiple disciplines including theater, film, dance, music, comedy, writing, entertainment, media, and more to make art and create a community for these artists. ASAP aims to celebrate the community, experience, culture, and history of Asian students at Harvard with events such as group discussions, movie screenings, workshops, open-mic nights, group outings, panels, and large- and small-scale performances and theatrical productions.

Let us act as a catalyst in bringing Black women and other gender marginalized students on Harvard University's campus together for academic, cultural, political, and social purposes. Let us find strength, support, and courage in our unity and combine our intellect, spirit, and resources so that we may best address the needs and problems of Black gender marginalized students at Harvard College and within the University as a whole. Let us be actively engaged in the larger discourse on gender marginalized issues, particularly those pertaining to Black gender marginalized people, on Harvard University's campus, nationwide, and worldwide and contribute our energies to these causes. Lastly, let us maintain an interest and commitment to the overall Black experience, both within and outside of the Harvard community. The Association of Black Harvard Women will firmly commit to the works of anti-racism and gender inclusivity, while welcoming and celebrating the stories of all gender marginalized people. We will also uplift the voices of the Black queer community and engage in unwavering activism by condemning injustices on—and off—campus. Finally, we will advocate for the end of rape culture, sexual assault, and sexual harassment on and beyond campus, prioritizing the safety and well-being of survivors.

Our vision is to create visibility and liberation for every sex, sexual orientation, gender identity, and gender expression in sports. Activate athletic communities to exercise their leadership to eliminate homophobia and transphobia in sports
To celebrate Australian culture.

The Bach Society Orchestra, popularly known as BachSoc, is Harvard’s premier chamber orchestra and is staffed, managed, and conducted entirely by undergraduates. We are committed to the study and performance of works for chamber orchestra, from intimate chamber pieces as well as mid-sized symphonies, selected from a range of historical periods, and to cultivating a strong community within the ensemble. BachSoc is similarly dedicated to increasing the accessibility of orchestral music; all of our concerts, which take place at least twice each semester, are free-ticketed and open to the public.

The Bengali Association of Students at Harvard (BASHA) is a cultural organization concerned with promoting the unique aspects of Bengali culture and fostering community among students with roots in Bangladesh, West Bengal, and the diaspora, as well as others with interest in the region’s rich history and traditions. Through our various social, cultural, and academic programming, we seek to provide members of the Harvard community with a home away from home, as that is what basha (বাসা) means.

The Black Arts Collective works to address the on-campus social and systemic issues of how Black artistic and creative expression is too commonly disregarded by general art communities and derailed by those made uncomfortable by its presence. We build affinity through artistry by hosting events and makerspaces that center healing and joy as a method of collective liberation. Our makerspaces provide a safe space for Black students to create, regardless of skill level and experience, for various creative disciplines, including but not limited to dance, painting, writing, photography, film, music, multimedia, and performance art. Our events are fun activities for everyone in the community to participate in, regardless of any interest in the arts. These include things such as parties, speaker events, art festivals, concerts, and workshops. We plan to have an annual showcase/festival of local Black artists including spoken word poetry, short films, dance performances, and original plays.
BlackCAST is a Harvard student-run organization whose primary purpose is to stimulate interest & support for Black theater on campus.

The mission of the Brattle Street Chamber Players is to perform string orchestra and chamber music at a professional level while exploring and promoting a greater understanding of both traditional and contemporary repertoire that is largely inaccessible to more traditional Harvard orchestras. Without a music director or conductor, we are committed to upholding the ideals of musical democracy, with logistical and musical endeavors solely led by student members. Our goal is to create an inclusive and collaborative community where all members can grow as musicians and contribute to the vibrant musical community of Harvard and beyond.

The Harvard Catholic Student Association invites the greater Harvard community to grow in a meaningful relationship with Jesus Christ through Catholic worship, inquiry, prayer, and service, forming disciples who use their gifts for the flourishing of the Church and the world.
To create a Harvard community where all members value wellbeing. We cultivate individual and collective growth through educational experiences that develop and enhance holistic health.

We are a group of Harvard, Stanford, and UChicago undergraduate researchers who conduct pro bono economic policy research for governments, intergovernmental organizations, and policy think tanks. We are supported by an annual cohort of PhD candidates, professors of economics, and industry professionals.
Our mission is to bring together students of all identities to celebrate Colombia and Colombian culture.

Harvard's Common Spaces are designed to bring the University community together. To create areas on campus where students, faculty, staff, and visitors can engage with one another, discover and try new things, or simply relax. To accomplish this, we are committed to: Providing collaborative spaces where students, faculty, and staff can explore, enjoy, and create Harvard's academic, cultural, and social offerings. Creating events and programs with an array of partners across the University. Supporting our community with communal spaces where everyone can fully participate in the opportunities offered.

Our mission is to serve as a superstructure to give the Latino community greater cohesion and a stronger sense of solidarity among its diverse special-interest groups. Concilio Latino was historically the University-wide organization that provides a forum for dialogue, coordination, and communication for the Latine cultural, performing, political, social and publication groups on campus. Although University-wide in its scope, Concilio is currently focused on the Harvard undergraduate community in order to firmly establish itself as a student group. Concilio Latino's long-term goal, however, consists of incorporating the different Latinx groups from all the different schools at Harvard University. This year, Concilio will be redefined as a mediating, representative body to a) forestall event conflicts, b) publicize said events, and c) collaborate on large-scale, community-wide efforts.

As technology continues to advance and play an increasingly central role in our lives, the intersection of art and technology helps us understand the complex and rapidly changing relationship between humanity and technology. Through researching, critiquing, and developing cross-disciplinary, innovative media that integrates technological development with artistic practice, the Conflux collective (confluxcollective.org) aims to expand the intersection of contemporary art and cutting-edge technology, pushing both towards a synergistic responsible, inclusive, and humane future. Conflux provides a supportive ecosystem for artists to challenge and critique the dominant narratives and power structures that shape our society, and for technologists to consider the ethical and social implications of their work. Moreover, through creating large-scale, participatory installations, Conflux practices what it means for humans and technology to create together.

The Crimson Key Society is a sovereign student organization with a mission to make Harvard welcoming and accessible for students and visitors alike. To do so, the Crimson Key Society has a purpose to: 1.	To give tours to prospective students, tourists, and visitors through various University Offices. 2.	To work with Harvard College to coordinate social aspects of First-Year Orientation Week. 3.	To perform, in cooperation with Harvard University authorities, any other services deemed beneficial to Harvard University.
CrimsonEMS shall provide the Harvard University Community, in the Area of Service, with Basic Life Support (BLS) emergency medical care.

Datamatch’s mission is to help students find love and friendship on their campus. We run Harvard’s (and other universities’) Datamatch tradition, which include an annual matchmaking survey, dates, and other events to encourage students to meet each other within their student body. In the fall, we also run a matching survey for first-years to meet each other once they get on campus, and in the spring, we collaborate with the Senior Class Committee to run the Match series of senior matchmaking.

Dharma provides space for members of the Harvard community to celebrate Hindu festivals, to learn and practice Hindu values and traditions, and to discuss the South Asian and Hindu experience. Central to Dharma’s mission is the Hindu belief that there are many paths toward spiritual growth and fulfillment. This ideal is reflected especially in the inclusive nature of Dharma’s community and social events.

ECHO provides the Harvard community with peer counselors who are trained to listen empathetically and to support students through a hotline and drop-in office that are confidential and non-judgmental. Additionally, ECHO validates diverse experiences of body image and eating concerns by facilitating campus conversation through outreach events.

Eleganza aims to use the power of fashion, dance, and music to unite students of all identities and cultural backgrounds, redefining beauty and aesthetics in the community and spotlighting diverse student experience and talents through our fashion and choreography. We strive to support this message not only by highlighting inclusiveness and marginalized identities in our show but also donating all of our proceeds to charities that align with our mission.

The Harvard Eritrean & Ethiopian Student Association is an organization dedicated to creating an undergraduate family, serving our local & international community, and sharing our diverse cultures with the world.

Harvard's Expressions Dance Company (EDC) is a completely student-run company showcasing hip hop dance. Founded in 1978 with its inaugural performances in the spring of 1979, EDC has a long legacy of artistic achievement which spans other forms of contemporary dance beyond its current focus on hip hop. The company is built on three guiding principles, which we strive to promote in all areas of the organization: Creativity, Confidence, and Community. From company-wide social events to a series of open workshops, Expressions seeks to create a community on campus, bringing students together to dance, socialize, and learn from one another. All members, regardless of tenure or leadership, hold a valuable stake within the company and are to feel respected and encouraged at all times. In Expressions, we urge our choreographers and dancers to incorporate a variety of styles into their movement and to use diverse choreography as a platform for their stories, emotions, and concepts. We welcome dancers to develop their relationship with hip hop through their own experience and understanding of other dance genres, techniques, and inspirations.

We are the Fallen Angels, Harvard's premier, upper-voice, contemporary a cappella group founded in 2001. Every year we hold auditions, perform in Sanders theatre, and participate in additional gigs. Our goal is to make music and have fun doing it!

Fig. Magazine is Harvard’s fashion media platform. We showcase our campus’s creative talents and promote the values we want to see in the fashion industry via our print/digital publications, and on-campus events. We’re working to create a more inclusive, approachable, responsive, and sustainable industry by collaborating with brands that interrogate fashion’s power at both the individual and social levels, challenging understandings of sexuality, gender, sustainability and body.

The Food Literacy Project (FLP), is HUDS' food education initiative. With focuses on sustainability, nutrition, food preparation and community, the FLP seeks to empower everyone to make informed food choices. Every undergraduate house/dining hall has a fellow; FLP also has a presence at GSAS.
To create a progressive Jewish learning, thinking, researching, and community space on campus rooted in questioning all things – including Zionism.

Friends of Project Sunshine at Harvard College’s mission is to give Harvard undergraduates the opportunity to bring programming - recreation (arts), educational (tutoring and mentoring) and social service (HIV and nutritional counseling) - to children facing medical challenges and their families in the Boston area and beyond, by partnering with the Project Sunshine Project, which extends across 175 major cities across the United States and in four international satellite sites: Canada, China, Israel, and Kenya. Friends of Project Sunshine at Harvard College would focus on free services for medically challenged children and their families in the greater Boston area.

We are Fuerza Latina, Harvard College's Largest pan-Latine organization on campus. We strive to promote issues related to the Latine community, and advocate for inclusion in ALL academic and social spaces on campus.

1. Greener Scott Scholars will promote mentoring between graduate and undergraduate students on an individual and group basis increasing students’ self-confidence and their sense of belonging. 2. Greener Scott Scholars will improve mentee/mentor interpersonal, leadership, and relationship skills while supporting the mentee as they adjust to Harvard’s culture and environment. 3. Greener Scott Scholars will provide opportunities for specialized engagement and growth, as well as access to Harvard faculty, staff, and experts who understand minority dynamics through lectures, panels, and/or workshops for the collective group via club-wide 3-4 meetings per semester.

We are the Group for Undergraduates in Statistics at Harvard College (GUSH), Harvard's first and only group dedicated to fostering an enthusiastic community for statistics - an extremely applicable, powerful, and fascinating field.

We hold a computer science and engineering intercollegiate conference with 500+ students from all over the world every fall. We aim to foster a strong community of outside-the-box thinkers and innovative doers among Harvard and the global community. http://hackharvard.io/

The Harvard African Students Association, founded in 1977, is an organization committed to nourishing cultural, intellectual, political, and economic awareness about the African continent. We are the Harvard community for students from Africa, connected to Africa, or interested in matters concerning Africa. Anyone who is intrigued by lively debates, art shows, cultural shows, music, and African cuisine will find a welcoming home at HASA. We are dedicated to building community and promoting collaboration amongst African students at Harvard, encouraging awareness of Africa within the Harvard community and the greater Boston area, and ultimately contributing back to our continent.

The Harvard Archery Club's mission is to introduce Harvard affiliates to archery in a warm and welcoming environment while also providing a space for Harvard affiliates to practice. Archers are welcome to bring their own equipment!

The Harvard Architecture Undergraduate Society is dedicated to fostering the appreciation of architecture and the world of design at Harvard College. The club provides a forum for students exploring a wide range of academic disciplines to learn and contribute to the discussion on the built environment. Through seminars, excursions, workshops, and guest speakers, HAUS is a space to visualize the world we want to live in.

The Harvard Association Cultivating Inter-American Democracy is devoted to strengthening and promoting democracy throughout the Western Hemisphere; the acronym HACIA is Spanish for “towards.” Thus, our name helps to convey our main objective. In establishing HACIA Democracy as a Harvard student organization, each member is committed to the following:

Harvard Ballet Company is a student-run organization at Harvard College that performs classical ballet, contemporary, and modern dance. Our biannual shows feature choreography by alumnae, Company members, professional guest artists, and world-renowned choreographers. HBC also offers weekly ballet classes to all members; our Company classes are usually taught by our own Company members and professional guest artists. In addition, we hold a variety of community-building events and offer mentorship opportunities from our alumni. Harvard Ballet Company has quietly grown into one of America’s premier student dance groups. Since its creation in 1993, the company has continued to gain talented dancers, rising choreographers, and fresh ambition. Harvard Ballet Company looks to further students’ dance education through a supportive atmosphere, classes, and performances, while simultaneously encouraging their academic passions

The Harvard Ballroom Dance Team is a competitive dance team with no comp process, no auditions, no cuts, and no partner or experience necessary. We welcome all who want to learn how to ballroom dance, whether you've been dancing for 10 years or 10 seconds. We offer beginner classes for all Harvard affiliates, and we travel to Brown, NYC, and Montreal! With Harvard Ballroom, you're ready to own the floor. Check out our page, and feel free to message us with any questions!

The Harvard Black Men's Forum catalyzes the agency of Harvard undergraduate black men. We support our members through our core pillars of brotherhood, masculinity, and fidelity. Working with faculty and national figures, we provide a forum for discussion and action on issues pertinent to our body. We additionally seek to provide support for disadvantaged members of this country through various service initiatives like the David Walkers Scholars Program, a tutoring and mentoring program.

The purpose of the Harvard Black Students' Association is to establish a sense of community, or more appropriately, communities amongst Black students on campus. The BSA shall endeavor to establish and promote interaction among Black students at Harvard College in inclusive and welcoming environments for all. The BSA seeks to uplift the voices of those who have been most marginalized such as Black women, Black queer folks, Black disabled folks, and Black low-income folks. In addition, the BSA shall endeavor to promote interaction among all members of the Harvard community.

The Harvard-Radcliffe Caribbean Club was founded in 1978 by a group of Caribbean students who aimed to foster a space where students of Caribbean descent and appreciators of Caribbean culture alike could bring some of the Caribbean’s warmth to the cold city of Cambridge. Founded during a period of increased Caribbean immigration into the United States, the Harvard Caribbean Club provided community and a voice on campus for the growing number of Caribbean students. Today, The Harvard Caribbean Club is made up of Caribbean international students, American-born students of Caribbean descent, and those who simply care to learn more about the small yet mighty region. Together, we celebrate our shared histories and traditions while also appreciating and learning about our differences. And together, we work toward our goal of promoting greater awareness of the people, affairs, and contributions of the Caribbean within our Harvard Community and any other spaces we enter.

Harvard Chabad is a home away from home for every Jew on campus. A place where students of all backgrounds and degrees of observance can enjoy exploring the Jewish heritage in a warm, welcoming, and non-judgmental environment. Chabad seeks to engage fellow Jews at their own pace and comfort level through innovative programs in all areas of Jewish life. Among our programs, we host weekly Shabbat dinners that provide students an elegant setting in which to meet new friends from every niche of the Harvard campus, experience the beauty of Jewish life and community, and explore and deepen their Jewish identity. Our creative holiday programs on the Harvard campus raise Jewish consciousness and pride throughout the university. Our lectures and classes on Jewish law, philosophy, and ethics, teach the relevance and depth of our heritage to our leadership community.

The Harvard Chemistry Club serves as a meeting place for undergraduate chemists at Harvard and a venue for chemical education initiatives tailored for undergraduates. Open to concentrators in Chemistry, Chemistry and Physics, and Chemical and Physical Biology, as well as to all students interested in chemistry, the Harvard Chemistry Club holds regular social gatherings, faculty dinners, seminars, and advising events.
Promote chess on campus and the general Boston area

We seek to introduce students to Jesus Christ, help them to grow in their faith, help them connect with the needs of the community around them, and inspire commitment to follow the example and teachings of Jesus throughout their lives.

The Classical Club provides a wide variety of opportunities for enthusiasts of ancient Rome, Greece, and their corresponding languages and cultures to promote and celebrate the Classics. The club's activities include, but are not limited to, monthly dinners, classically-themed movie nights, the translation and production of a Greek or Latin play for the wider audience on campus, and the occasional toga party. The club also sponsors Persephone, a journal for undergraduate scholarship, translation, creative writing, and art inspired by the Classics. During the spring semester, club members organize and host the Harvard Certamen, a Classics-based quiz-bowl-style tournament for high school students that attracts schools from across the nation. Excitingly, in Fall 2023, we will begin formal planning for our Spring 2024 production of Seneca’s Medea!

Act on a Dream is a student-led, student-run organization at Harvard College focused on supporting and advocating for the immigrant community on campus, our local community, and beyond. We have four pillars: Advocating for legislative measures like comprehensive immigration reform and the abolishment of ICE, focusing on permanent solutions. Building a community on campus that welcomes all migrants and backgrounds. Pushing Harvard administrators to increase support for all undocumented students, TPS workers, and other members of our community, while centering community needs and demands. Engaging in service to help the larger undocumented community

The Albanian Students Association is an organization that unites students of Albanian origin and students interested in Albanian culture, history, and contemporary issues. The organization will raise awareness of social, economic, and political conditions that affect Albanians throughout the world through: community discussions, cultural (music/food/film) events, forums, and networking events.

Harvard College Association for Yan Xin Qigong is concerned with the learning and exploration of Yan Xin Qigong (also referred to as Yan Xin Life Science and Technology) - the foremost representative of the traditional Chinese health and science system – in the Harvard community by appropriate means such as publications, meetings, seminars, and other research and educational activities. The organization will host all the learning and practice activities under the academic and technical guidance of Dr. Yan Xin. All the activities of the group are not any form of medical treatment or substitution for medical care and will organize all the activities abiding by the rules and regulations of Harvard and IAYXSLT; The group is against any forms of banned group activities by any country, and would adhere by local and international laws and regulations of anti-terror, health, social justice.
To promote academic curiosity and healthy competition in the game of quizbowl, and create a community built on a shared love of learning.

Founded in 1997, Harvard College China Forum is dedicated to a constructive dialogue on the challenges, trends, and issues affecting China. The forum aims to engage leaders in business, academia, and politics in a discourse that offers insights and generates ideas. HCCF is North America leading and longest-running student-run conference on China. The forum takes place every April in Boston, Massachusetts. Over a thousand delegates and nearly a hundred speakers attend the forum, making it the largest of its kind.

The Harvard College Chinese International Students Society (HCCISS) is a vibrant and inclusive organization dedicated to fostering a sense of community, cultural appreciation, and mutual understanding among Chinese international students and those interested in Chinese culture at Harvard University. Our mission is to celebrate and share the rich heritage of China, support the growth and development of our members, and promote cross-cultural exchanges that enhance the educational experience for all students.

Harvard College Christian Students (HCCS) is a group of Christian believers at Harvard from diverse backgrounds who love the Lord Jesus and hold the Christian faith which is common to all believers. We are committed to helping the Harvard community realize and participate in the eternal purpose of God as revealed in the Bible, as well as exploring how it applies to daily life through developing a living relationship with Jesus Christ.

The intent and purpose of the Harvard College Debating Union (HCDU, formerly the Harvard Speech and Parliamentary Debate Society) is to develop and pursue excellence in debate in the Harvard community, and to represent Harvard University in intercollegiate parliamentary debate competitions. In addition, HCDU will seek to sponsor, organize, and run events and programs that make accessible the benefits of public speaking and debate to wider society (including, but not limited to, organizing competitions in collegiate and high school formats, demonstration debates, and community service projects).
Established in 1829, the Harvard College Democrats has been evolving ever since. We maintain a strong Democratic community at Harvard and empower our members to help build a better society.
Partner with communities and develop leaders to build a better world.

The purpose of the Generational African-American Students Association (GAASA) is twofold: to (1) foster community between students identifying as Generational African-Americans, the larger Black community, and Harvard University as a whole and (2) raise awareness and spark social change on issues pertaining to the heinous legacy of slavery in the United States.

The Harvard College Georgian Student Association is concerned with creating an inclusive space for Georgian students and raising awareness of Georgian culture within the Harvard community. The Harvard College Georgian Association will plan activities to foster belonging of Georgian students while allowing them to share their heritage with their peers. We also intend to create a space for cultural exchange of ideas, language, art, music, and food.

The Harvard College Indian International Students Association aims to: 1. Create a welcoming environment for Indian international students to connect, share experiences, and support one another. 2. Promote Indian culture, heritage, and diversity through events, workshops, and outreach activities. 3. Facilitate networking and mentorship opportunities among students, alumni, and professionals. 4. Advocate for the interests and needs of Indian students within the broader Harvard community.
We aim to build community among Iranian Americans at Harvard through kabob dinners, events with students at other universities, and speaking engagements with influential Iranian Americans.

The Harvard College Korean International Student Association is concerned with the political, social, cultural, and educational issues regarding Korea. It will address these concerns by fostering mentoring relationships between the underclassmen and upperclassmen, and establishing and maintaining contacts in Korea.
The Latter Day Saint Student Association is established to help students find community and support in balancing their academic, social, cultural, and religious education.

Founded in 2004 by a group of Nigerian undergraduate students, the Harvard College Nigerian Students Association has grown both in numbers and respect, becoming one of the premier organizations for students on campus. Based on the shared culture and values of Nigerian and Nigerian American students, Harvard NSA has not only created a community for Nigerians to come together but has also spread an appreciation for the Nigerian culture throughout campus through various activities and events.

For 30 years, we have made it our mission to introduce Harvard College students to the art of opera, and to provide opera performance opportunities to undergraduates. Today’s Harvard College Opera brings together singers and players to enable, empower, and organize collaborative art making across disciplines and outside institutional boundaries, all while striving for excellence in our own season of events, both programmed and informal.

HCPSA is dedicated to promoting the unique aspects of Pakistan's culture and society, bringing together all students with an interest in Pakistan. HCPSA is also dedicated to being the primary resource for students seeking information and advice as a liaison to Pakistan. HCPSA seeks to serve as the representative organization on the college campus for all matters pertaining to Pakistan.

The Harvard College Polish Society is concerned with the political, social, and cultural issues regarding Poland. The Society will seek to promote greater awareness and understanding of these issues in the Harvard community through activities including, but not limited to, meetings, film screenings, talks and cookouts.

Our mission is simple: we connect the top leaders of today and tomorrow in a dynamic forum of exchange. The Harvard College Project for Asian and International Relations (HPAIR) was founded in 1991 to create a forum of exchange for students and young professionals to discuss and learn about the most important economic, political, and social issues facing the Asia-Pacific region. Since 1991, HPAIR has organized 49 conferences in 34 different host countries, touching the lives of more than 40,000 students and young professionals. HPAIR hosts two student-led conferences a year – one on Harvard’s campus and one in the Asia-Pacific. Prospective host cities in Asia must undergo an intensive, six month bidding process; this year’s Asia Conference will be held in Hong Kong.

The Harvard College Queer Students Association (QSA) is a resource organization concerned with improving the visibility, strength, and support of lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, queer, questioning, and allied students, initiatives, organizations, and communities, in recognition of the marginalization that exists as the result of stigmatized identities. This group seeks to promote community and awareness of and be a resource with respect to the social, socioeconomic, political, educational, and cultural issues surrounding queer identities and sexualities in the form of events driven toward creating safe spaces in collaboration with other groups, institutions, and communities.

Provide exposure to Russian-speaking cultures, societies, and the language to help the student population become more informed on Russian-speaking countries. Allow heritage/native speakers to find a community of people with a similar background where they are welcomed and encouraged to explore their identity. Immerse students of the Russian language in the cultures and promote language learning. Provide students with an open floor to speak freely about their experiences and ideas through events and meetings. Create a sense of community amongst all Russian-speakers.

We are a student-run organization on a mission to empower children - including children with chronic illnesses - to dream big by providing a free, online, one-on-one mentorship program to create their own storybooks.

Our organization is a chapter of the larger organization Massachusetts Menstrual Equity, whose goals include fighting period poverty in Massachusetts and beyond as well as removing the stigma surrounding menstruation. At Harvard, we have acted on these initiatives by ensuring that all restrooms have period products available to students, and hope to expand our impact by fostering a community where periods are no longer a taboo subject of conversation.

The purpose and mission of Harvard Undergraduates for Uyghur Solidarity is to bring conversations, knowledge, and advocacy on the Uyghur crisis into conversations at the University. The group plans to host speaker events that focus on the academic and political parts of the human rights crisis. In addition to this, cultural showcases, displays, and celebrations are meant to disseminate the Uyghur culture and language to students at a time when the Uyghur people are facing a mass ethnic cleansing and genocide in Occupied East Turkistan.

Established in 2000, the Harvard College Students Piano Society (HCPS) is dedicated to fostering piano performance, pedagogy, and appreciation both within and beyond the Harvard community. We are devoted to forging a more intimate and united community of musicians, providing performance opportunities for student pianists and connecting pianists with the wider Harvard arts community. HCPS hosts masterclasses, workshops, and recital series with pianists from around the world. We welcome both amateur and professional pianists, and even non-musicians who just love music.

HCTSA's mission is to: (1) promote an inclusive community for Turkish students at Harvard. (2) promote the exchange of ideas for a better understanding of Turkish people, their culture and history. (3) To present the interests of its members in dealing with the Harvard University Administration and various student organizations, (4) To provide an environment for interaction among its members, their families, international communities, Harvard University students, staff, and similar college associations.

The Harvard College Union Society is an undergraduate community dedicated to free inquiry and civil discourse. Our group debates the most salient issues facing Harvard and the larger American body politic without fear in the face of controversy.

HWC is a non-commercial association of undergraduates and other persons in the Harvard University community interested in Amateur Radio, organized for the promotion of interest in Amateur Radio communication and experimentation and education, for the promotion of public service with regard to amateur radio in the community, for the establishment of emergency communications in the event of disasters or other emergencies, for the advancement of the radio art and for the maintenance of collegiality and a high standard of conduct.

The Harvard Community of Humanists, Atheists, and Agnostics aims to encourage consciousness of the various political, scientific, social, and cultural issues surrounding secularism and Humanism. Accordingly, HCHAA sponsors events, panel discussions, debates, social functions, and other educational and cultural programs. HCHAA welcomes members of every gender, ethnicity, religious background, and sexuality. We seek to maintain a positive and communicative relationship with other religious and political groups on campus, and welcome our responsibility to give back to the community, lending support to community service and political campaigns affecting secularism or Humanism.

The mission of HCA is to provide undergraduate students with semi-professional experience in composing, producing, and administration that they otherwise would not find through classes in the Harvard Music Department or elsewhere in the University. Harvard music classes, while they may offer performance opportunities for new works, do not offer room for students to understand the production of their works or to interact and organize musicians in a way that will be required of them professionally. With the decline of record company budgets, nowadays all musicians are essentially independent business owners, and sufficient resources are needed to replicate that type of environment. Additionally, all HCA composers will have primary ownership of their recordings, allowing them to publish works online to build portfolios. This decision is in line with the current trend seen at Berklee and other institutions to allow student ownership of works created while on campus. Students will also explore the legal side of the music business to understand contract terminology and publishing.
Harvard Computer Society empowers Harvard students with the resources, opportunities, and community to forge their path in computer science.

The Harvard Cycling Club is a student-run club sport for cyclists of all levels. The team competes in the Eastern Collegiate Cycling Conference in the spring, and some members go on to compete in local-, regional-, and even national-level events in the summer. Anyone is welcome to join us! Please visit our website with more information about how to get started with HCC: https://www.harvardcycling.club/membership. Questions? Email us at harvarducycling@gmail.com. Join our mailing list at https://groups.google.com/forum/#!forum/harvardcycling.

Founded in 1892, the Debate Council is one of the oldest and proudest intercollegiate policy debate programs in the nation.  Committed to excellence in both competitive and educational achievement, Harvard Debate has won the National Debate Tournament (NDT) seven times, most recently in 2016, and finished second five times, since the tournament was first held in 1947.   The NDT records show that Harvard Debate has been invited to attend the tournament every year since 1954 – a record of consistency unmatched by any other school.  In recent years, Harvard Debaters have won every major national policy debate invitational. For two years in a row, in 2016 and 2017, Harvard won the Rex Copeland Award for the Top First Round At-Large Team at the NDT awarded to the team with the best individual record in the regular season.

Founded in 1996, the Harvard Financial Analysts Club (HFAC) is dedicated to providing the Harvard student body with sound financial education programs and real-world investment experience. Through the HFAC comp, new members are given a ground-up introduction to finance with a focus on internship/career preparation. After completion of the comp, students can help manage HFAC's $40K equity investment fund, a portfolio under the direction of the club's student and alumni members. In addition to its weekly comp and fund meetings, HFAC hosts guest speakers from both academia and the finance industry.

The Harvard Glee Club is dedicated to furthering the tradition of tenor and bass choral music, to foster lifelong fellowship, and to improve ourselves and our community through the love and and performance of music.

Harvard Hillel is a Jewish home on campus that seeks to: - Welcome students to experience the variety of Jewish identity, tradition, practice, values, culture, and community. - Inspire and enable Jewish connection, celebration, and action. - Prepare students to join, create, shape, and lead Jewish communities; strengthen the Jewish people, and live proud Jewish lives. - Share Jewish sources, traditions, ideas, and innovations, and their relevance in our world. - Forge connection and engagement with the State of Israel. - Foster friendship in a nurturing and refreshing sanctuary amid the stresses of student life. - Engage the unique opportunities of Harvard and make Jewish thought and culture integral in the life of the University.

As Harvard College's weekly undergraduate newsmagazine, the Harvard Independent’s purpose is to provide in‐depth, critical coverage of issues and events of interest to the Harvard community. The Independent has no political affiliation, instead offering diverse commentary on news, arts, sports, and student life.

ICMUN is concerned with educating Harvard students about international issues, the United Nations, and the skills of diplomacy and compromise by providing students the opportunity to participate as delegates in collegiate Model United Nations conferences.

The Harvard International Relations Council is the heart for international relations on campus. We are dedicated to promoting awareness of international issues throughout Harvard and around the world through educational programs and cultural connections.

The purpose of the Harvard Program for International Education shall be to create and foster interest in international relations in high school students from local schools & pre-professional skills in students from humanitarian crisis nations. The Program's primary focus shall be to enable Harvard College students to conduct non-partisan discussion tutorials in these schools. The aim of this tutorial program is to communicate an understanding not only of the current state of world affairs but also of the theoretical foundations underlying this state, and to present this material to high school students in a manner accessible to them. Each semester of the program shall end with a role-playing simulation or exercise to which all of the participating schools will be invited. Every effort will be made to accommodate the logistical concerns of the participating schools.

The Harvard International Review is a quarterly magazine offering insight on international affairs from the perspectives of scholars, leaders, and policymakers. Since our founding in 1979, we've set out to bridge the worlds of academia and policy through outstanding writing and editorial selection.
Learn the quantitative and qualitative skills behind investing with a group of like-minded peers.

The Society’s goals are: (1) to provide an environment for members to practice Islam as a way of life; (2) to assist the broader community at Harvard University in their spiritual, social and intellectual endeavors; and (3) to provide a better understanding of Islam to the University community.

Our central mission is to promote awareness about social, political, and cultural issues regarding Korea. All students are welcome to join— whether it is to find a tight-knit community, connect on the basis of Korean heritage, or simply learn more about different aspects of Korean culture.
Mentor

Founded in 1986, Harvard Model Congress is a 501(c)(3) educational nonprofit and the nation's oldest government simulation conference run exclusively by undergraduates at Harvard College. First and foremost a teaching institution, HMC dedicates itself to providing an enjoyable and instructive atmosphere in which to develop a commitment to and interest in American government and civic engagement. Our primary goal is to teach and inspire the leaders of tomorrow.

To educate and foster the next generation of global leaders by offering a truly interactive program, featuring one-on-one communication with Harvard students, debate on pressing global issues, and cross-cultural connections among delegates from throughout Asia and around the world.

The mission of Harvard Model Congress Europe is to provide a platform for high school students from around the world to engage in constructive dialogue and debate on pressing global issues. We strive to cultivate critical thinking, leadership skills, and a deeper understanding of the complexities of international affairs among our participants. Through our simulated congressional committees, we aim to create a collaborative and inclusive environment where students can develop their public speaking, research, and negotiation abilities. We believe that by fostering empathy, intellectual curiosity, and an appreciation for diversity, we can inspire the next generation of leaders to make a positive impact in their communities and beyond.

Model Congress Middle East, a government simulation conference in the Middle East, is a 501(c)(3) nonprofit organization founded in 2012 and dedicated to teaching, inspiring, and connecting high school students from across the world.

Founded in 2001, HMCSF is one of the best civic engagement conferences under the umbrella organization of Harvard Model Congress, the nation's oldest government simulation conference run exclusively by undergraduates at Harvard College. First and foremost a teaching institution, HMC is also the most dynamic model congress simulation available to high school students. Over the course of the three-day conference, HMCSF offers students the unique opportunity to assume the role of real-life senators, congressmen, and members of special programs to inspire debate, cooperation, and legislation--while also forcing students at the same time to expand their own perspectives and to understand the issues at hand in a new, more nuanced way.

Harvard Model United Nations is the oldest, largest, and most prestigious high school Model United Nations conference. Begun decades years ago with a simulation of the League of Nations, Harvard Model United Nations is the product of years of constant innovation and a commitment to substantive excellence. While our conference has expanded considerably since its incipience, now representing delegates from over 50 nations across the world, Harvard Model United Nations is committed to the same high standard of experience for every individual delegate. Harvard Model United Nations 2025 will continue to offer innovative and challenging committees, cutting-edge technology, and, of course, loads of entertainment for delegates outside of the committee.
Foster skills and a common love for mountaineering and hiking for outdoors enthusiasts of all levels.

Harvard National Model United Nations is the oldest, largest, most prestigious model UN conference on the collegiate circuit. For now seven decades, HNMUN has been an annual forum for hundreds of college students from dozens of countries from around the world.  Every year, delegates from around the world come to Boston to discuss pressing international issues and defend their positions passionately. They learn how to negotiate with other people and collaborate with like-minded representatives. They work together on policy proposals and detailed programs in order to solve important global problems on a wide range of international topics.

Founded in 1980, the Opportunes are Harvard's oldest (and boldest) all-gender a cappella group. With repertoire ranging from the pop anthems of Ariana Grande and Beyonce to the timeless classics of Stevie Wonder and Michael Jackson, the Opportunes are known for their energetic performances, intricate student arrangements, and award-winning discography.

HOLA seeks to promote greater awareness and understanding of the political, social, and cultural issues regarding the countries of Latin America and the people who inhabit them in the Harvard Community. At the same time, HOLA seeks to provide a warm social space for Latin American students, in addition to other interested students, at Harvard College.
The Harvard Outing Club exists to help members of the Harvard community get outside. Beyond leading weekly trips, HOC operates a gear collaborative and offers a forum for like-minded individuals.

By providing an avenue for students to come together in a friendly, inclusive environment centered around a sport that's accessible to a wide range of skill levels, HPC contributes to the development of well-rounded individuals who not only excel academically but also value the importance of physical health, community, and social engagement. Pickleball brings diverse people together: no matter your athletic background, pickleball is unique in its ability to be easily learned. This club builds existing and new social connections, provides an opportunity to explore fitness, to let loose and enjoy the sport and other's company, and teach the value of teamwork and collective unity to help serve the greater Harvard purpose of empowering individuals to contribute to society.

Founded in 1969, the Harvard Political Review (HPR) is an undergraduate-run journal of politics, policy, and culture. The review addresses domestic and international affairs, as well as political discourse on campus. It also conducts interviews with political figures and experts ranging from Alan Derschowitz to Anthony Fauci to Kara Swisher. The HPR features student perspectives in the form of articles, podcasts, investigations, and data-driven storytelling. Staff writers work closely with editors to strengthen pieces while maintaining their distinct journalistic voices. Aside from the standard publication route, students are encouraged to participate in a wide variety of programs including the Red Line Investigative Fellowship, the Summer Fellowship, and Columns. They can also pitch topic ideas for and contribute to our quarterly magazine. Previous issues include “Isolation” (Fall 2020), “Girls Girls Girls” (Winter 2019), “Engineering Earth” (Fall 2018), and “Body Politic” (Summer 2014).

We, the members of the Harvard Pops Orchestra, endeavor to provide the Harvard community, the students, faculty, affiliates, and patrons thereof, with unique musical experiences. Through seasonal concerts built around creative themes, presenting an eclectic range of music from classical to jazz to rock, and employing theatrical and visual elements, we strive to create events that are not only enriching, but also highly enjoyable. In addition, we aim to cultivate the musical expertise of our musicians by scheduling regular rehearsals, as well as by encouraging students to conduct, arrange, orchestrate, or compose original works to be performed by the orchestra. Our overall goal is to play music at a very high level for the entertainment of the Harvard community.

The purpose of the Harvard Program for International Education shall be to create and foster interest in international relations in high school students from local schools & pre-professional skills in students from humanitarian crisis nations. The Program's primary focus shall be to enable Harvard College students to conduct non-partisan discussion tutorials in these schools. Every effort will be made to accommodate the logistical concerns of the participating schools.

Harvard Radio Broadcasting, Inc. (WHRB, 95.3 FM) is a non-profit, commercial radio station run entirely by undergraduates. We have over 220 active members, an FM dial which reaches over 4 million people in the Greater Boston area, and 10 departments, which include classical music, jazz, blues, the record hospital (rock/punk/indie and more), the darker side (hip-hop/r&b/edm and more), sports, news, sales, studio engineering, and tech. We also produce live shows featuring local artists, online content including interviews, reviews, and other journalistic pieces, and podcasts of all kinds. We are a vibrant and diverse community serving the Harvard, Cambridge and Greater Boston communities as an educational and cultural resource. And we want YOU to join WHRB's warm and welcoming community! Absolutely no prior experience or knowledge is required or expected! Our "comp" stands for COMPLETION, not competition! For more information about joining, please email president@whrb.org or comp@whrb.org. Feel free to check us out at www.whrb.org or find us on Instagram (@whrb95.3) or Facebook!

The Harvard Republican Club exists as a home for Republican students on campus. We host social events and guest speakers to promote conservative ideas on campus, as well as support Republican candidates for local, state, and federal office.

HROTCA seeks to preserve the longstanding tradition of military service at the College and advocate for the cadets and midshipmen sworn to protect and serve the United States. Through activities, social events, and community engagement, we not only hope to build a strong camaraderie within the club, but also foster positive relationships with the student body as a whole.

The purposes of the Review have been and shall be to solicit and receive manuscripts of philosophical articles, interviews with philosophers and other philosophical writings; to edit and regularly publish, in various forms of media, a philosophical journal; to distribute the journal within the University undergraduate and graduate academic community, as the officers may determine from time to time; to distribute the journal to university libraries, philosophy departments, other educational institutions and the broader public; to arrange for and to present annual or semi-annual philosophical lectures at the University; if the officers see fit, to organize and sponsor regular bi- monthly or other regular symposia for students (“Reading Groups”).

SHPE Harvard SEAS Chapter strives to empower the Hispanic/Latino community at Harvard by supporting its members to realize their full potential and to impact the world through STEM awareness, access, support, and development.

Our chapter mission, in alignment with that of the national organization, is to “stimulate women to achieve full potential in careers as engineers and leaders, expand the image of the engineering profession as a positive force in improving the quality of life, and demonstrate the value of diversity” (SWE).

The Society of Arab Students brings together Arab students at Harvard for cultural celebration and community connection, offering a space for Arabs and non-Arabs alike to learn more about Arab culture and engage deeply with one another.

The Harvard Society of Black Scientists and Engineers seeks to support Black Harvard students pursuing degrees in life sciences, engineering, applied sciences, and other STEM fields. Our primary aim is to foster a sense of community among Black students in STEM at Harvard through offering academic and career advising, professional development workshops, help in the job and internship search, and various social events. We also seek to impact the wider Cambridge community by encouraging students to pursue STEM through mentoring and tutoring. Ultimately, we strive to combat underrepresentation in the sciences by facilitating the growth of black scientists at every level.

Harvard College SoulFood Christian Fellowship is a student group committed to demonstrating seeing Jesus’ hope and restoration coming to the Black Community at Harvard.  We seek to nurture deep relationships with God and each other through community events, bible study, worship, and service in the Harvard community and beyond.

The Harvard South Asian Association exists to meet the political, cultural, academic, and social needs of students who express interest in the region of South Asia and the South Asian diaspora. South Asia includes but is not limited to the nations of Afghanistan, Bangladesh, Bhutan, India, the Maldives, Myanmar, Nepal, Pakistan, and Sri Lanka.
To educate, empower, and inspire Harvard College students with meaningful employment opportunities and hands-on business experience

The Harvard Taiwanese Cultural Society (hereafter referred to as TCS) shall be dedicated to the following goals: 1. To advance the understanding of and interest in Taiwanese culture and related issues in the general Harvard community; 2. To cultivate friendship among students and scholars from Taiwan, of Taiwanese background, or have interests in the Taiwanese culture; 3. To promote contact with alumni around the world
We are the Harvard Undergraduate Aerospace Collective dedicated to promoting space exploration and interest in space.
Our primary mission is to encourage undergraduate students to learn more about foreign affairs, diplomacy, and military issues in support of a strong American foreign policy.

The mission of the Harvard Undergraduate Allies for Angels is simple: to be there when pediatric patients need it most. Supporting local pediatric hospitals such as Boston Children’s, Mass General for Children, and Shriners Children’s, as well as both local and remote non-profit organizations that support pediatric patients, our student-led organization—under the remarkable support and advising of Dr. Weston Northam of Boston Children’s Hospital—will ally together for these angels so that we may do everything we can to bring light into their life’s darkest moments, so that they may have the support they need not only to navigate their health condition, but to learn to thrive with it in all aspects of life.

The Harvard Undergraduate Alnisa’s Medical Alliance strives to foster a community of support and positive encouragement for Muslim female pre-med students of Harvard College. Harvard Alnisa is concerned with offering a platform for Muslim females at Harvard College either interested in or pursuing the pre-medical pathway. We believe there is a real need to empower this community through providing resources and mentorship for their advancement on the pre-med track, promoting the values of Islam in their goals and aspirations as future physicians, providing education on issues related to women’s welfare and health, and building a genuine camaraderie among students identifying as a member of this community. This organization will also serve as a forum for students to address the challenges faced by the broader Muslim female physician community and serve as a space of solidarity. Appreciating the slowly changing demographics of physicians in the United States starts with uniting the Muslim female pre-med community on Harvard’s campus.

The Harvard Alternative Investment Club (HAI) is Harvard College’s first and only student organization dedicated to private equity, as well as other non-traditional investments. Visit our website to learn more!
HAWC’s mission is to strengthen Arab sisterhood on campus and foster discussions surrounding women’s rights and empowerment in the Arab world and beyond.
The purpose of this organization shall be to create a space for Arkansans and Arkansas lovers to come together and forge connections with each other and alumni from and within the state of Arkansas.

The Harvard Undergraduate Art History Society aims to create a community of students to discuss and explore art history through both on-campus activities and museum excursions. Members of the organization will explore the multidisciplinary reach of art history through additional guest lectures and panels with people ranging from museum curators to art critiques, and to professors. A diversity of perspectives is vital to a nuanced understanding of art and so the multidisciplinary nature of the subject will be fully embraced.

The Harvard Undergraduate Arts & Crafts Club was founded to create opportunities for students of all identities, disciplines, and artistic backgrounds to create, appreciate, and celebrate the arts. The ACC was founded by a group of sub-par (arguably terrible) artists of different disciplines, class years, and identities who share at least one thing in common: none of them have had any formal training in the arts. In fact, some feel that their talents never developed past finger-painting. The ACC firmly believes in the power of some good old arts & crafts, by bringing people together in a low-stakes, accessible, and fun setting.

For over twenty years, the Harvard Asian American Dance Troupe (AADT) has sought to spread an appreciation and awareness of Asian culture through dance. Our repertoire includes a diverse range of dance forms including traditional, ethnic minority, martial arts, modern, ballet, hip-hop, and fusion. In AADT, students of all cultural and dance backgrounds participate in bringing the variety, skill, and vibrancy of Asian dance to the stage. AADT is proud of our non-audition, all-are-welcome policy. Our pieces are student choreographed or arranged and feature both undergraduate and graduate dancers. We hope to encourage interaction and collaboration with other dance groups on campus and make AADT a reflection of Harvard’s diverse and creative environment.

The mission of the Harvard Undergraduate Association is to provide all Harvard College students with the best possible college experience. The HUA supports student voices, invites all students to participate, and is a central avenue for advocacy for the student body. In accordance with such, the HUA efficiently, reliably, and transparently promotes and protects student rights, such as providing a long-lasting, safe, and open forum for students to collaborate.

To create unique, accessible, life-changing educational experiences that impact thousands of students across China annually while simultaneously facilitating enriching cross-cultural teaching opportunities for Harvard students.

The Harvard Undergraduate Association of Ghanaian Students is concerned with creating a close undergraduate community of Ghanaian students through the coordination of events and conversation that allows all members to feel valued, included, and empowered to succeed with the support of one another. Our organization was founded in the summer of 2022 when five students from Twi AB (Benista Owusu-Amo, Emma Mensah, Maame Forson, Verda Annan, and Yvonne Burke) came together to form what is now known as HUAGS. In our first year of operation, we hope to meet on a consistent basis, document all meetings/finances, plan at least two events per month, and ultimately connect all undergraduate Ghanaian-identifying students. We plan to host a Ghanaian Independence Day celebration annually. As we embark on this process, we hope to expand to include graduate students, more board positions, and outreach into the Cambridge community and beyond.
Create a welcoming atmosphere for Harvard undergraduates concentrating in astrophysics to learn more about the concentration and potential careers in the field.

The Harvard Undergraduate Austrian German Association provides a welcoming and supportive space for students with a German educational or cultural background in order to share experiences of American culture and as Harvard students, including discussions of specific challenges associated with being a German Harvard College student, such as the transition from a German educational system to an American one. HUAGA thus focuses on welcoming Harvard freshmen and exchange students from German universities by providing them with a network of students who have gone through a similar process and on whom they can rely for advice and support in administrative, cultural, and social matters. The Association helps German students stay in touch with their home country by having a home community away from home, while fully involved in their life at Harvard. Additionally, the Association serves as a forum for discussion about German politics, current events, and the like. To fulfill this mission, HCGSA will hold welcoming events for newcomers at the beginning of the school year, pairing them with upperclassmen, as much as possible from a similar background, and familiarizing them with the broader Harvard campus and with Cambridge and Boston. Bi-weekly dinners will foster a sense of community and provide a supportive network for all members. We also aim to build a strong alumni network of German Harvard College graduates. HUAGA graduates could then help current college students plan for future academic and professional opportunities back in Germany or Europe in general. h as possible from a similar background, and familiarizing them with the broader Harvard campus and with Cambridge and Boston.
