The Harvard Undergraduate Automotive Society is built around our Formula SAE team, where students design, build, and test a formula-style race car to compete in the annual FSAE competition. The competition includes static, dynamic, and presentation events that challenge students in engineering design, manufacturing, business strategy, and team communication. Our goal is to prepare undergraduates for careers in engineering and industry by giving them hands-on, team-based experience. Alongside our technical work, we host motorsport watch parties and community events to share our passion for the automotive world.

Our mission is to ignite a passion for the aviation industry in individuals by fostering a dynamic and inclusive community. We aim to inspire curiosity and knowledge through engaging events, hands-on experiences, and educational resources.

HUBS seeks to create a dedicated, long-lasting space to promote the cultures, traditions, histories and languages of the Baltic states by contributing to both local, multicultural communities and global networks.

We started with an idea in the Harvard Community Garden, but have since become an independent club. In the past, we have partnered  with the Food Literacy Project to bring bees into the important farm to table picture, and the Health Advocacy Project with a small honey-tasting event. Since 2006, honeybee colonies in the US have seen collapse rates of up to 90%. As key pollinators, honeybees are directly responsible for cultivation of over 30% of the most important food crops. HUB seeks to stimulate active discussion on campus about not only the plight of the honeybee, but also to educate about the incredible world of apiculture. We would seek to bring together groups with important stakes in the fate of beekeeping. From all parts of the Harvard community, from the RoboBees Laboratory designing robots that mimic hive behavior at the School of Engineering & Applied Sciences, to the Environmental Exposure biologists working to link between declining bee health and pesticides at the School of Public Health.

The Behavioral Strategy Group (BSG) is a Harvard College student-led organization working to apply academic insights in behavioral economics to solve real-world problems. Our team provides consulting services and is dedicated to helping startups, companies, and organizations overcome challenges by designing behaviorally informed interventions. Our group organizes events that allow students from across the world to interact with world-renowned scholars and business leaders. Our community started at Harvard College but is expanding to include students from schools around the world who strive to apply behavioral economics insights to solve the issues they care about.

Harvard College Bhangra is concerned with meeting the artistic and cultural needs of students who express interest in the Punjabi dance form of Bhangra. Harvard College Bhangra addresses this purpose by: exposing the Harvard community to the art form of Bhangra through campus performances, fundraisers, and showcases, representing Harvard in competitive venues in the Boston area as well as nationally, teaching Bhangra to any and all individuals who are interested through, creating a social and cultural community for team members

The Harvard Undergraduate Biomedical Sciences Forum is dedicated to helping students build the skills to communicate scientific knowledge to audiences of all levels. The club hosts dynamic scientific presenters to discuss cutting-edge biomedical techniques with a focus on broadly applicable analytical thinking and fundamental principles. These events prepare students to understand and communicate future breakthroughs. Such skills are critical for undergraduates who will enter into scientific communities, science and technology policy arenas, as well as other fields. The club will host faculty members to demonstrate how fundamental scientific techniques and interdisciplinarity can advance diverse biological and medical fields. After hearing these presentations, members choose relevant peer-reviewed publications to present either individually or in groups at presentation dinners.

The Harvard Undergraduate Biotechnology Club (HUBC) aims to provide students with access to academic experts, industry leaders, and seasoned investors in technology and the life sciences. We strive to provide education and hands-on training for students to explore and experience the broad range of careers that exist in biotechnology. HUBC is committed to increasing diversity, equity, and inclusion of underrepresented groups at Harvard in both academia and industry.

1.  The BCL should be responsible for making larger grander decisions for the community. 2.  The BCL should promote collaboration to groups that appeal to the Black community at Harvard. The BCL should promote synergies rather than be a totalitarian governing body. 3.  The BCL should foster neutrality in making big Black community decisions 4.  The BCL should be a unified voice to outside the Black Community. There should be strength in numbers. The BCL should work together on initiatives of importance on campus.
Our mission is to create a space for health activism on campus and provide students with opportunities to critically engage with the Boston and Cambridge communities to address health disparities.

The Harvard Undergraduate Black Muslim Collective is concerned with recognizing, honoring, and celebrating the unique experiences, struggles, and identities of Black Muslim students on campus. BMC works to shed light on the experiences of Black Muslim students as they navigate these multiple identities as well as create and foster a sense of community among those who hold these identities.

The Harvard Undergraduate Black Pre-Law Association, founded in 2006, is dedicated to providing exposure, information, and resources to students–black students in particular–pursuing entrance into legal institutions and careers involving law. Although aiding the minority pre-law population is primarily our goal, exposure is not exclusive to those who are underrepresented. We aim to inform and be beneficial to all who are interested in pursuing law. We seek to offer resources that will enhance educational and professional opportunities for all students, while specifically targeting the needs of minority groups who remain underrepresented as members of the legal community. Furthermore, it is the responsibility of the organization’s executives to attract speakers, recruiters, and partners who are equally committed to ensuring that more students from these groups will be provided with resources that will aid their ability to be competitive candidates for law school admission.

The mission of HUBPS is to expose Black students—historically underrepresented in healthcare—to opportunities in the medical field. The organization aims to serve as a safe and encouraging space where Black students can discuss and navigate the unique challenges they face in medicine, particularly those relating to race and healthcare disparities. By focusing on case studies, hosting panels with Black medical professionals, and engaging in conversations about inequities in healthcare, HUBPS seeks to empower and uplift students interested in these fields.

Harvard Undergraduate Blockchain aims to build a multidisciplinary community that explores the future of blockchain, crypto, and decentralized technologies. Through education, collaboration, and real-world engagement, we empower students to lead innovation in Web3 and beyond.
To provide a safe space for board game and snack enjoyers every Saturday night. Open to everyone whether they come once or every week.

The Harvard Undergraduate Book Club (HUBC) seeks to promote reading for leisure outside of class, to facilitate engagement with the humanities, and to foster discussion about literature of all kinds. Through our monthly meetings, we hope to establish a vibrant community of book lovers, where students of all disciplines and walks of life learn about themselves and one another through the common act of reading. We believe that reading with others provides unquantifiable and long lasting psychotherapeutic benefits, and hope to make our community a better place by sharing the gifts of reading to all those around us. In addition, HUBC seeks to conduct community outreach by publicizing our reads on social media, hosting guest talks, and collaborating with external organizations to promote literary engagement across Harvard and beyond.

The purpose of the Harvard Undergraduate Brazilian Association is to promote awareness about Brazilian culture at Harvard, as well as foster a community for students from and/or interested in Brazil throughout campus.

The mission of HUBC is to foster connections between Bulgarian and Bulgarian-identifying students on campus, as well as provide a space to celebrate Bulgarian culture, open to anyone on Harvard’s campus.

Harvard Undergraduate Candela Latin Dance Troupe is a non-competitive performance dance group committed to celebrating and disseminating Latin culture through an array of genres. The group also seeks to bring awareness of Latin American culture to the greater Harvard and Boston communities.

Harvard Undergraduate Capital Partners is an early/growth stage investment advisory student organization on campus that works for venture capital clients and exposes students to venture capital. We focus on giving students access to an unparalleled network of VCs, unique work experience with real clients, exclusive internship opportunities, and a tight-knit community passionate about entrepreneurship and venture capital. We believe that students should have access to real world experience in investing and entrepreneurship, as well as tangible access to funding and mentorship for their ventures. Follow us on Instagram (@harvardundergradcapital) or visit our website (harvardundergadcapital.org) for more information.

The purpose and mission of the Harvard Undergraduate Central Asian Student Association (HUCAS) is to engage students from across the University in active dialogue about Central Asia and to serve as a cultural affinity space for Central Asian students to host events and celebrations.

The Harvard Undergraduate Chapter of Amnesty International, a chapter of Amnesty International USA, is a student organization founded in 2023 that is dedicated to advancing human rights on Harvard University’s campus and beyond. We are committed to human rights advocacy through grassroots activism, organizing events, and directing campaigns that raise awareness and promote the basic human rights to justice, freedom, and truth.

Girl Up is a by girls, for girls movement in which we aim to achieve gender equality by educating our communities and empowering those around us to take action so that every girl can reach her full potential. It is our mission to uphold the values set forth by the United Nations Foundation and Girl Up, stated above. The Harvard College Chapter of Girl Up exists to bring awareness, support, and solutions to gender equity issues facing the self-identifying girls and women in the Harvard College and local communities.

Harvard Undergraduate Christian Fellowship (HUCF) is a campus ministry that reaches college students from all backgrounds with the hope of Jesus Christ. College is a time when beliefs are explored, decisions are made, and lives are changed. We invite students into authentic relationships and the study of God’s Word. Through the ministry of HUCF, students discover the love of Christ, find their significance in God’s redemptive story, and engage in the life of His church.

To accelerate the clean energy transition through interdisciplinary education and climate action. Our group provides tools and opportunities to undergraduate students hoping to make an impact within the clean energy space, including: Speaker events Tours of local clean energy facilities and companies Faculty and alumni conversations Clean energy journal Volunteering with community energy initiatives Workshops Inter-college energy networking Member projects focused on innovation, equity, policy, and engineering.

The Harvard Undergraduate Climate Coalition(“HUCC”) is an organization comprising undergraduate students and student groups that serves as a space for connection, communication, and collaboration on climate and environmental topics within and beyond Harvard. The idea for the HUCC came out of concerns from students already involved in undergraduate climate and environmental activities on campus. Many groups have fractured students among singular interests (i.e., conservation, clean energy, environmental justice, plant sustainability, service) as opposed to embracing students interested in other environmental niches or climate more generally. There is desire for a non-competitive, community-focused, student-led group in this area. We aim to be a community hub, helping students to create connections and share ideas. We aim to show students how the climate intersects with each of our lives in countless unique ways. We are committed to upholding our principles of diversity, equity, and inclusion and centering the voices and leadership of those who are most affected by the climate crisis as we work toward a more sustainable and equitable future. We are committed to being non-exclusive and invite anyone to become a member of the group, attend our events, and engage with our projects.

To provide our clients with research and recommendations at industry-leading standards and to build a supportive, educational community where Harvard's best students can grow professionally and personally.

CBE provides students with a hands-on opportunity to apply their unique academic and personal backgrounds to address pressing real-world problems. With an emphasis on the environment, we work to enact tangible change in the sustainability, technology, and life sciences sectors. In doing so, we aim to foster a diverse community of Harvard College students equipped with skills to become future leaders in society.

As Harvard’s only pre-professional contemporary dance company, we provide a space for trained individuals to learn, grow, and be inspired by other talented dancers. We hold weekly rehearsals where dancers take class to refine their technique and work on a new choreographic piece. We offer multiple performance opportunities throughout each semester.

The Harvard Undergraduate Creative Writing Collective is concerned with filling the gap in the creative writing community on Harvard’s campus. Through mentorship, drop-in hours, networking events, book clubs, workshop events, speaker series, and service opportunities, we ultimately seek to create a radically inclusive, tight-knit community for writers of all kinds on campus (& beyond), by: •	Providing support and accountability for writers working on projects •	Connecting writers with publishers, nonprofits, grants, and each other •	Organizing writing & non-writing related events & programming •	Partnering with other creative orgs at Harvard •	Serving the greater Boston community

The mission of the Harvard Undergraduate Crimson Cellos is to foster a vibrant community of cellists by establishing Harvard's premier cello ensemble. Crimson Cellos aims to spread musical diffusion by challenging cello misconceptions, which include its believed ability to play only classical music and role as a relatively less prominent instrument in the orchestra. Our ensemble enriches both the Harvard campus and the greater Boston area through rehearsals, jam sessions, and performances at venues like Arts First, the Harvard Art Museum, and local hospitals. Additionally, we host speaker events and educational opportunities to inspire others to pursue music and encourage deeper engagement with this beautiful instrument.

The Czech and Slovak Club at Harvard College aims to foster a vibrant and diverse community for students, alumni, and faculty with an interest in the culture, history, and heritage of Czechia and Slovakia. Through cultural events and community outreach, we seek to promote understanding and appreciation of the shared traditions and modern developments of both nations.
In our work, build positive meaningful, impact. In our clients, create lasting and substantial improvements. In our students, provide excitement and opportunities for development.

Harvard College Deepam is a South Asian classical dance group. We have performed at various campus events, including Ghungroo, Arts First, and Cultural Rhythms. We choreograph our own routines, and focus on combining traditional form and technique with our innovations and experimentation. Our mission is to be a space for South Asian classical dancers to practice, learn, grow, and - most importantly - to find a community.
Harvard Undergraduate Design Collective’s mission is to expand digital arts education, celebrate Harvard artists, and empower you to pursue design.

The Harvard Undergraduate Disability Justice Club (HUDJ), founded in the fall of 2021, is working to build a large coalition of students with chronic illnesses, mental illnesses, and visible/invisible disabilities, as well as allies, dedicated to making Harvard College more accessible. The club is centered on students’ lived experiences, but we welcome and encourage any undergraduates at Harvard College to join. You do not need to disclose your disability (or have one) to join or participate in club activities!

The Harvard Undergraduate Dominican Student Association is a cultural organization created to celebrate the Dominican and Dominican-American experience. We seek to provide students who are Dominican-identifying and those who want to learn about Dominican culture with a safe space to feel both represented and welcome. As an organization, we emphasize the inclusion of all identities and want everyone on campus to feel comfortable thriving in the space that’s provided by DSA. Through our various branches, we emphasize the importance of providing members with a safe social space, establishing professional networks to connect members to Dominican professionals and alumni, and of giving back to the Dominican community outside of campus.
The HUEA strives to create a more inclusive economics community at Harvard and beyond. We believe economics has much to contribute in making sense of the major issues that face our generation.

We, the students of Harvard Undergraduate Effective Altruism (HUEA), are a group of undergraduates dedicated to doing the most good possible with our lives. We strive to help create a lasting community that uses evidence and reason to find the most effective ways to improve the world. We are mindful of our immense privilege and aim to make the most of the exceptional opportunity we have to effect positive change in the world. We are curious, open-minded and think critically and are willing to ask hard questions in order to help us figure out how to make the biggest change we can, both in our lives and while at Harvard.

The Harvard Undergraduate Electronic Music Collective provides a collaborative and supportive environment for electronic music enthusiasts to have intimate learning opportunities with world-class producers/DJs (ex: Paul Van Dyk, Armin Van Buuren, Madeon etc) to refine their music and DJing skills through workshops, guest lectures, and collaborative events.

The Harvard Undergraduate Engineering Society (HUES) promotes engineering and cross-disciplinary collaboration of Harvard College students at the Harvard John A. Paulson School of Engineering and Applied Sciences (SEAS). Our board consists of a diverse group of over twenty undergraduate engineering students, drawing strength from our unique backgrounds, disciplines, and perspectives.

Our goal is to encourage collaborative and accessible discourse on pressing ethical issues and to supply students and the wider public with an ethical toolkit that they can productively apply to their daily lives.

The Harvard Undergraduate European Initiative seeks to create a space to discuss and learn about European politics, history, and culture at Harvard College. Through its events, HUEI strives to create a vibrant community for all students interested in Europe. At the same time, HUEI seeks to foster a sense of community among international students heading to Harvard from European countries—especially those from under-represented countries.

The purpose of Harvard Undergraduate Faith and Action, by God’s grace and power, is to create an environment that develops and nurtures mature Christian leaders for every sector of society. The group will seek to promote greater awareness and understanding of the Holy Bible and the Christian faith in the Harvard community by appropriate means such as speakers, Bible courses, Bible studies, retreats, book discussions, leadership training, community service, fellowship, and other activities. It also seeks to serve as an authentic Christian witness to the Harvard community, expressing the Good News of Jesus Christ, as set forth in the Holy Bible, through all of its activities and challenging Christians to develop a Biblical worldview and to live lives of increasing faithfulness to Jesus Christ.

The Harvard Fed Challenge Team is a small, tight-knit group on campus that analyzes macroeconomic conditions, formulates monetary policy recommendations, and presents them to leading economists at the Boston Fed and at the Board of Governors in Washington D.C. as part of the National College Federal Reserve Challenge.

The Harvard Undergraduate Film Club organizes weekly screenings to promote the appreciation of film. HUFC is open to all: our movies sample diverse perspectives from all of film history and all parts of the world. Members enjoy the company of fellow movie-lovers while watching carefully curated films in a welcoming environment.

Harvard Undergraduate Food Lab aims to empower kids to cook and make healthy food choices. Volunteers teach weekly after-school cooking lessons for K-12 students at local youth and community health centers. Our classes help develop valuable cooking skills, as well as teach relevant concepts in nutrition, healthy eating, food science, history, and culture. Harvard Undergraduate Food Lab provides a collaborative environment for Harvard students with a passion for cooking to gain hands-on teaching experience while serving the greater Cambridge-Boston community.

The mission of the Harvard Undergraduate Food Security Initiative is to promote the health and wellness of the Harvard community by addressing the stigma surrounding food insecurity, connecting students and affiliates with supplemental food resources, and working to establish/maintain a permanent food pantry at Harvard University.

Harvard Undergraduate Foreign Policy Initiative (HUFPI) is Harvard's premier student-led foreign policy organization, connecting undergraduates of all identities and perspectives to the world of foreign policy decision-making.

The mission of Harvard College Forensic Speech is to equip undergraduate students in becoming public speakers, educators, and presenters about a wide variety of topics, while providing a venue to compete and share their voices with larger audiences.

We are part of a non-profit organization on a mission to bring improved healthcare to communities in the developing world! Since our founding in 2003, we have been dedicated to improving pediatric and maternal health in the developing world. Our chapter works to improve the health of children both here and abroad by teaching about health in our local community, collecting and sending supplies to FIMRC clinics worldwide, promoting awareness of these issues, and fundraising for projects that will contribute to FIMRC's vision of a world in which all children have an equal opportunity to benefit from modern medicine.

The Harvard Undergraduate Francophone Society exists to satisfy the cultural, linguistic, political, academic, and social needs of the students interested in the francophone countries and communities around the world. It provides the opportunities for students to celebrate and enjoy the ties of a shared language: French.
We are a student-run organization dedicated to the learning and practice of video game development.

Our mission is to promote gender inclusivity in the math department at Harvard, create a supportive and connected community within the department, and provide opportunities and resources to students who would like to be more involved in mathematics.

Harvard Undergraduate Ghungroo is concerned with creating a student-run production centering South Asian and South Asian diaspora culture through music, dance, spoken word, skit, writing, and visual art. We will present research and perspectives on South Asian mainland and diaspora culture to a wider audience every year, continuing a 30+ year tradition. We create a space for undergraduate students across the college to explore South Asian culture and heritage through the arts. We hope to work in collaboration with existing South Asian affinity groups and performing arts groups to create a cross-cultural production. Our acts include skits and theater, spoken word poetry recitations, storytelling; instrumental arrangements, various choral ensemble pieces, and classical music acts, folk, pop, fusion, and classical dances that capture regional and trans-regional traditions; a set consisting of panels, balconies, floor pieces, and ceiling pieces.

The world is faced with a severe shortage of healthcare resources. Those who are most in need of help are often ignored by the major players in the medical space. GAMI aims to leverage the technical expertise and passion of students around the world as well as the invaluable experience of healthcare professionals to develop impactful technologies, policies, and programs and make healthcare accessible to all.

The Harvard Undergraduate Global Education Movement is concerned with utilizing education in enabling students with the tools they need to think big. Our mission is twofold: (1) to lead professional development conferences, encouraging students to become globally-minded problem solvers (2) to serve under-resourced communities through workshops, equipping students with the practical skills they need to seek university admission and/or employment. Essentially, the Harvard Undergraduate Global Education Movement is composed of a group of Harvard undergraduates who realize that, as students of one of the world’s most highly regarded institutions of higher education, we have the opportunity and responsibility to use the education we are receiving to inspire those not as fortunate. We want the promise of education to extend far beyond Harvard’s gates, and far beyond our borders.

The purpose of Global Research and Consulting is to connect a diverse group of remarkable students, united by a passion for creating global impact, and provide opportunities for them to develop their research and consulting skills and cross-cultural awareness. Collaborate with a variety of non-profit global institutions to develop well-informed and impactful insights and solutions. Cultivate global and social mindfulness on the Harvard University campus by hosting events featuring social, public and private sector leaders
Our mission is to empower women and girls globally through spreading awareness and fostering education.

The Green Medicine Initiative aims to promote environmentally friendly practices in hospitals and other medical facilities as well as address the effects of climate change on human health. We devise cost-effective methods to aid healthcare facilities in reducing waste and energy usage in order to lower overall healthcare costs and promote environmental responsibility while educating about the role of healthcare institutions in the necessary sustainable transition.
HUGPT is a peer therapy program where students get support in building healthy and fulfilling relationships.

Our mission is to celebrate, empower, and unite individuals of mixed Asian heritage by providing a supportive community that embraces and promotes cultural diversity, identity exploration, and education. We aim to foster a sense of belonging, understanding, and pride among our members, while also advocating for awareness, inclusivity, and representation in the broader community.

Harvard College Hawaii Club aims to serve both the community of Hawaiian students attending Harvard College and the general student community at large by practicing and promoting the unique island culture on campus.

This organization is formed to: 1) Publish scholarly work in health policy, healthcare, and health law fields from academics, professionals, and students. 2) Provide students with the opportunity to learn about peer-reviewed publishing. 3) Provide a forum for a multidisciplinary discussion of health care policy. 4) Provide information and resources to students interested in health care and the changing landscape of medicine, through various speakers, meetings, publications, and other activities.

At the heart of our society lies a profound respect and passion for the rich heritage of Greece. We aim to foster a deeper understanding and appreciation of Hellenic culture among the Harvard community. Through our activities, we seek to create a welcoming space for students of Hellenic descent and those interested in the Hellenic world, fostering connections, dialogue, and cultural exchange.

As Harvard College iGEM (International Genetically Engineered Machine), we seek to establish a community of creative synthetic biologists from a variety of concentrations and disciplines. Our work each year will culminate in our participation in the iGEM competition where we will share our projects with an international audience, connect with other teams of synthetic biologists, relevant companies, and organizations.
We are a non-comp, open acceptance club dedicated to stimulating debate and discussion around International Relations issues

The mission of an Italian Society is to promote an appreciation and understanding of Italian culture, language, and heritage among its members and the wider community. Through a range of cultural, educational, and social activities, the Italian Society aims to foster a deeper understanding of the rich history, traditions, and art of Italy, as well as the contemporary Italian society and its contributions to the world. The Italian Society also seeks to provide opportunities for language learning and proficiency in Italian, as well as opportunities for members to connect with one another and build lifelong friendships based on a shared passion for Italian culture. Ultimately, the Italian Society strives to inspire its members to become global citizens who are committed to promoting cross-cultural understanding and making a positive impact in their communities.

The mission of the Harvard Undergraduate Jain Society (HUJS) is to foster a supportive community for undergraduate students interested in Jainism, promoting personal growth, spiritual development, and a deep understanding of Jain philosophy. We aim to share the principles of non-violence, compassion, and environmental sustainability with the broader Harvard community.

HUJI passionately boosts Japan's prominence at Harvard & beyond by creating meaningful connections and fostering mutual understanding. Bridging cultural gaps via vibrant student & organization exchanges, HUJI celebrates Japanese culture, art, and history while promoting cross-cultural dialogue. By collaborating with various institutions and hosting diverse events, the organization contributes to a global community where knowledge and experiences are shared, enriching lives and inspiring future generations. 🇯🇵🌉🌏

HUJPN is a think tank led by undergraduate students at Harvard University and a Recognized Student Organization (RSO) at Harvard College. Membership is open to students and scholars at academic institutions throughout the nation. We aim to establish a nationwide platform where students, particularly undergraduates, come together to learn about Japan's policy issues with scholars and prominent figures in each field. The issues include domestic circumstances from inflation and population decline to Japan's relationships with foreign nations, particularly China and the United States.

The Harvard Undergraduate Japan Society celebrates the Japanese community and its presence on campus. From hosting monthly social events to expanding the network beyond Harvard College, we strive to give opportunities for students of Japanese and non-Japanese backgrounds to connect over our culture.
Harvard Undergraduate Jews for Peace is an organization of Jewish and allied students committed to the struggle for Palestinian liberation and to building a Jewish community beyond Zionism on campus.

The mission of HUKC is to build a community of diverse individuals who take an entrepreneurial approach to life—fostering growth in their bodies, minds, spirits, and communities. - Inspire and Empower: it’s easy to get caught in the mix of greatness on campus, but by giving everyone a chance to build their “daily resume” - the small, but essential daily wins that build confidence - it reinvigorates a sense of purpose and desire to challenge oneself in a number of ways. - Foster Community: clubs, teams, and programs exist, but they lack intersectionality, focusing only on the physical, intellectual, emotional, or spiritual aspects of life - we’re here to bridge that gap, providing value to core members and participants, without taking from them. - Support and Feedback: whether it’s setting a new goal or approaching the finish line of an ongoing race (not literal), this is a community that keeps members grounded throughout the process.

The Harvard Undergraduate Knitting Circle is concerned with bringing undergraduate fiber arts together within a relaxed environment. We provide undergrads from all class years, backgrounds, and experiences a space to come together around the fiber arts and build new friendships. Additionally, we aim to serve the greater community through the fiber arts. Each year, knitting circle members will organize a donation drive to a charity, such as a homeless shelter or animal welfare organization. Members will be encouraged to make items including blankets, hats, or mittens to donate to those in need.
The Harvard Undergraduate Kurdish Cultural Association aims to foster understanding, awareness, and appreciation of Kurdish culture, history, and values through educational and cultural events.

The Harvard Undergraduate Latina Empowerment and Development (HU-LEAD) Organization is committed to creating an environment that promotes Latina leadership and empowerment through the organization of an annual conference with attendees from across the nation. LEAD promotes the development of a professional network, introduces mentoring opportunities, and inspires women to reaffirm their commitment to their profession and goals. Our conference and supplemental workshops throughout the school year focus solely on professional development and the empowerment of Latinas to realize their full potential in entering society as leaders and professionals.

Latines in Health Careers is a pre-professional organization whose objective is to provide undergraduate students with the resources to fully pursue their interest in a health profession.  It shall also serve the greater Boston community and medically underserved communities throughout the nation by creating and facilitating the implementation of programs which aim to improve the health status of the pertaining population.

A student-run organization at Harvard that provides professional resources and support for Harvard Latinx students. LiFT's mission is to challenge the narrative of minority underrepresentation in industries such as business, technology, law, media and more. LiFT's presence on campus is threefold: pre-professional workshops, professional exposure, and a tight-knit Latinx mentorship network. These manifest in the form of industry panels, resume workshops, mentorship programs, networking nights, and more.
The Harvard Undergraduate Law Review endeavors to promote the study and understanding of law among Harvard College undergraduates and throughout the Harvard community at large.

YLC provides Harvard students with a hands-on opportunity to apply their unique academic and personal backgrounds to inspire the next generation of leaders. In doing so, we aim to nurture a diverse community of Harvard College students equipped with skills to create meaningful and memorable experiences for high school students, inspiring the personal growth of mentors and participants alike. Whenever possible, all decisions made by the organization should be filtered through these lenses to ensure that actions undertaken by the organization are reflective of this mission and make progress towards this vision.

The Harvard Undergraduate Line Dancing Club aims to operate at the junction between community, music, performance art, and culture. Sparking from an observed lack of opportunity to engage with line dancing on campus, the club was founded to foster a welcoming environment for all students, regardless of prior dance experience or cultural background, to express their passion for line dancing while simultaneously learning new skills.
The Harvard Undergraduate Linguistics Society is concerned with promoting awareness of linguistics and encouraging engagement in the topic.

Founded in 1999, we are one of Harvard's award-winning, contemporary co-ed a cappella group. We perform shows twice a year in Harvard’s historic Sanders Theatre, embark on world tours, and sing upon request at venues in and outside Greater Boston. Our members hail from all around the globe and from diverse academic backgrounds, but we are united by our dedication to the group and our love for a cappella. All songs we perform are selected and arranged by current and past members of the group. As a result, we sing music from a wide variety of genres, ranging from classic rock and hip-hop to top 40, R&B, jazz and everything in between.

Harvard Undergraduate Maarga aims to create a non-denominational space for members of the Harvard community to learn, discuss and practice the dharma as preached by the Lord Shakyamuni Buddha and the Buddhas that have come before and after him, enabling not only students from Buddhist families and backgrounds to continue the practises of their childhood, but also to educate other students about practises of the Buddhist world and of Buddhists around them. As Harvard aims to create a diverse living environment, where students live with individuals from different walks of life and where students continuously assess their values and interests, Harvard Undergraduate Maarga also aims to enable Buddhist students to celebrate their own unique identities and experiences, while opening up their experiences to the rest of the student body.

The Harvard College Marketing Group’s mission is to cultivate the next generation of marketing leaders by providing students with real-world marketing opportunities. Through strategic partnerships with external companies, we aim to deliver innovative marketing solutions while equipping our members with the experience necessary to excel in the evolving marketing landscape.

The Harvard Undergraduate Martial Arts Research Society was established to advance the study of martial arts by bridging this gap, aiming to unlock the vast potential in martial arts research and enhance our understanding of the discipline. Through our society, we invite practitioners and enthusiasts from various martial arts disciplines to collaborate and apply their academic expertise to cultivate a diverse research community that enriches both personal practice and the broader field of martial arts.

The Harvard Undergraduate Mathematics Association is a student group dedicated to serving the mathematics community at Harvard by organizing programs, social events, panels, and other activities open to any member of the greater Harvard community. Our initiatives serve our goals of enriching and strengthening the undergraduate math community at Harvard.

The Harvard College Meditation Club aims to create a community around the pursuit of living a more mindful, reflective, and skillful life. HCMC hopes to develop the meditation skills of its members and foster discussion of matters of practical importance. In short, HCMC is dedicated to creating a community which promotes human flourishing and the art of living well.

The Harvard Undergraduate Microbiology Society (HUMS) aims to promote student interest and engagement in microbiology education and research on campus. Our mission is to foster a collaborative environment for students passionate about microbiology through journal clubs, guest lectures, research conferences, and exploration of diverse applications in sectors like infectious disease, pharmaceuticals, food science, and the environment.

In response to the recent explosion of interest in the university-wide Mind, Brain, and Behavior (MBB) initiative, HUMBB was officially formed in the fall of 2002. We promote multidisciplinary dialogue about, awareness of, and interest in topics related to cognitive science, while working to provide a sense of community among students interested in these topics. Cognitive science is a highly interdisciplinary field. Accordingly, HUMBB represents a wide variety of academic interests, ranging from artificial intelligence to cognitive neuropsychology to behavioral economics.

Our chapter aims to promote awareness, education, and engagement in neurosurgical care, particularly in underserved communities. We will work in collaboration with Harvard Medical School Mission:Brain and alongside medical professionals to provide outreach, advocacy, and educational opportunities related to global health and neurosurgery. The chapter will bridge gaps in healthcare access worldwide by supporting neurosurgical initiatives globally and helping connect students and professionals with resources and events.

The Harvard Undergraduate Mock Trial Association is dedicated to furthering a passion for trial advocacy and the law at Harvard College. We are a student-run group which competes regionally and nationally in competitions organized by the American Mock Trial Association. These competitions consist of trying legal cases in front of real judges and attorneys. We seek to enhance and apply its members' acute analytical reasoning, strategic thinking, and rhetorical skills.

Our goal is to educate undergraduate students about details in the world of legal policy through the simulated legal argumentation that is provided through AMCA’s program. This would allow students interested in pursuing a passion for the law an opportunity to do so as undergraduates rather than having to wait until they are eligible to enter law school. By working closely with a case (provided by AMCA) and having an opportunity to either argue in front of a panel of judges or write a legal brief that contains their ideas, students will be able to develop their argumentation skills and gain knowledge about the inner workings of our legal system.

The Harvard Undergraduate Music Business Association (HUMBA) is a student-led organization dedicated to exploring the diverse facets of the music industry through interactive workshops, speaker events featuring industry professionals, industry trips, an annual conference, and networking opportunities

Music in Hospitals and Nursing Homes Using Entertainment as Therapy is concerned with using live musical performances and social interaction to build meaningful relationships between Harvard students and elderly/ill residents in the Boston/Cambridge area’s assisted living facilities. At least once every other week during the school year, MIHNUET sends a group of musicians to perform a diverse program accompanied by time for socializing.

The Harvard Undergraduate Negotiation Club is dedicated to educating and empowering students in the art of negotiation. Our mission is to provide comprehensive training in principled negotiation methods and practical techniques, enabling members to become skilled negotiators in both their professional and personal lives.

HUNSA is concerned with the creation of a formal space for Harvard college students from Nepal / of Nepalese descent or any college student interested in Nepalese culture to come together and collectively discuss matters related to Nepal and collectively celebrate their Nepalese heritage. This organization also seeks to establish itself as a representative of all matters pertaining to Nepal within Harvard College.

The Network of Enlightened Women educates, equips, and empowers women to be principled leaders for a free society. Educate – NeW educates women on campus and early in their careers on the principles of freedom and opportunity by hosting speakers, holding debates, and providing intellectual resources. In its education work, NeW serves as a thought leader, promoting independent thinking and providing intellectual diversity on college campuses and in public discussions on women, policy, and culture. Equip – NeW trains pro-liberty women to serve as leaders through campus sessions, national conferences, leadership retreats, and professional development programs. Empower – NeW cultivates a vibrant community of women through campus chapters, professional chapters, and our online presence that emboldens participants to confidently advocate for pro-liberty ideas in their schools, workplaces, homes, and communities. NeW also connects program participants with career-advancing professional opportunities.

The mission of the Harvard Undergraduate Nevada Club is to provide a space and community for Nevadans across the college to connect and get to know each other. In addition to this, the club will serve as a place to connect friends of Nevadans as a way to introduce them to our larger community.

Harvard Undergraduate Nordic Club is dedicated to fostering a community for Nordic students at Harvard University. The mission of the organization is to gather students with a shared background as well as preserve cultural traditions that these students share; these may include events ranging from informal social gatherings to the celebration of national holidays.  Harvard Undergraduate Nordic Club will benefit the Harvard community by creating an inclusive and accepting space for incoming, current and former Nordic students of Harvard University.

We're a student-faculty group that aims to increase transparency and solve problems on campus using public Harvard data. Our flagship product is Harvard’s first open data catalog, where we’ve gathered dozens of public Harvard datasets in a free repository. We’ve used data science and data visualization techniques to analyze data on campus safety, faculty gender disparity, student government election turnout, and trends in concentration popularity, to name a few. HODP’s community includes over 100 undergraduates as well as several Harvard faculty: Nick Sinai, the former deputy CTO of the US and current HKS professor; Jim Waldo, the former Harvard CTO; and others.

We aim to change the paradigm of biological research by making the resources and funding to do impactful research accessible to all. OpenBio provides the space, resources, funding, and advising to help students turn their research visions into reality. Through this community, we hope to enable meaningful research and change the culture of undergraduate biology at Harvard and beyond. We support student-led projects that have the potential to make a lasting impact on the world using biology. Additionally, we are committed to increasing access to scientific education and opportunities for underrepresented groups, as diversity is essential for progress and innovation. We are excited to work towards this mission and use biology to create a brighter future for all

The Harvard College Palestine Solidarity Committee is a non-sectarian student organization dedicated to supporting the Palestinian struggle for self-determination, justice, and equality through raising awareness, advocacy, and non-violent resistance.

Harvard Undergraduate Partners in Health Engage advances global health equity through advocacy, fundraising, and community building efforts. We directly improve global health outcomes through sustainable solutions founded upon cultural competency.
Help patients navigate their appointment, get answers to their questions and become involved in their care while training students in the world of medical care.

The purpose of this club shall be to serve as a “buddy” program for critically ill children receiving medical treatment in Boston.  The club shall work closely with other non-profit organizations including Christopher’s Haven, the Ronald McDonald House, and Hospitality Homes to provide physical, academic, and emotional support to the children and their families.  This support shall be provided through weekly visits to both Christopher’s Haven and the Ronald McDonald House, featuring group activities such as crafting, baking, and playing games, as well as through individual visits with Hospitality Homes families, meal preparation through Meals with Love, care package assembling and delivery, one-on-one academic tutoring, and fundraising.  Ultimately, our purpose is to support critically ill pediatric patients and their families as they undergo a difficult time in their lives.

The Harvard Undergraduate PGP Chapter (HUPGP) is an affiliated, campus-based organization 'of the Petey Greene Program (PGP). HUPGP is committed to supporting the academic and career aspirations of incarcerated and formerly incarcerated individuals through high-quality tutoring and educational initiatives in the Greater Boston area. Our mission extends to educating volunteers and the broader public about systemic injustices within the American carceral system, fostering awareness, and advocating for meaningful change.

The Harvard Undergraduate Philippine Forum (HUPF) is a close-knit family of Filipinos, Filipino-Americans, and friends that celebrates and shares the vitality of Philippine culture and tradition with the Harvard community. Through activities from traditional dance performances to food samplings, HUPF offers the campus community a glimpse of Filipino culture. With its social and educational events and the camaraderie it offers, it provides its members with a uniquely Filipino Harvard experience.

The goal of the Harvard Undergraduate Photography Club is to provide student photographers with the resources and artistic community they require to develop and grow their photographic skills. This community will give students inspiration and instruction through interaction with their fellow photographers and will help advance the visual arts on the Harvard campus.

Harvard Undergraduate Plant Based is a student-led organization broadly focused on accelerating the transition to plant-centric food systems at the intersection of social justice, public health, environmental sustainability, and animal welfare. We hope to educate and empower the next generation of leaders to bring about a more ethical, sustainable, healthy, accessible, culturally appropriate, and efficient plant-centric food system. The purpose of this organization is to create a space for students to learn about and partake in the transition to sustainable food systems. We aim to advance these goals using the following levers: - Influencing federal, state, and local policies and initiatives - Creating a plant-based community at the collegiate level and using this to effect change to food practices in university dining halls - Generating mainstream attention on plant-based solutions through media coverage, campaigns, and outreach - Collaborating with other student groups, non-governmental organizations, activists, and experts - Incorporating relevant food systems issues into our events and initiatives, ie. food desserts, food justice, equity, and accessibility

The Harvard Poker Club is concerned with the development of quantitative, analytical and perceptive skills acquired through the play and study of poker. We will educate the Harvard community on how card game playing can sharpen many important real-life skills in addition to being an enjoyable pastime, and through doing so build a community for poker enthusiasts on Harvard’s campus.

The Harvard Undergraduate Pre-Dental Society is committed to providing interested students with the information and opportunities necessary for succeeding in the pre-dental / oral health community on campus.

The Harvard Undergraduate Pre-Veterinary Society is concerned with promoting and stimulating interest in the veterinary sciences for interested students seeking to pursue or explore the field of veterinary medicine.

The Harvard Undergraduate Premedical Society is devoted to providing educational, support and volunteer opportunities related to medicine, and to foster the campus pre-medical community. We serve as a resource for students looking into a career to find out more about the profession and to meet important people in medicine. By encouraging the physicians of tomorrow to work together today, the Harvard Undergraduate Premedical Society does its part to build a spirit of cooperation, a spirit that is becoming ever more necessary in the medical profession.

The Harvard Undergraduate PreMedical Society for International Students is committed to empowering and supporting international students who want to pursue careers in healthcare in the United States. Acknowledging the unique challenges faced by international applicants—such as limited opportunities, complex admissions processes, and financial aid barriers—we strive to provide a welcoming community where students feel included, appreciated, and guided. The club also aims to implement different programs and initiatives around health advocacy, serving underserved communities, and working with various organizations and professionals to address issues such as access to quality healthcare, health disparities, and the social determinants of health. Our mission is to celebrate the invaluable skills international students bring, including cultural competence, cross-cultural communication, and global perspectives, which are essential to the practice of medicine. Through mentorship, workshops, admission panels, and networking with healthcare professionals from diverse backgrounds, we aim to create a space that fosters success, resilience, and community. The core of our mission lies in creating an inclusive, welcoming, and supportive community where students can learn from valuable mentors, physicians, and different healthcare professionals, as well as from each other, about navigating different resources and opportunities available to them inside and outside of the Harvard community. By connecting students with upper-level peers and alumni who have navigated similar paths, we ensure they have the resources, encouragement, and support needed to thrive despite systemic barriers. The club aims to empower students who have international backgrounds and are interested in engaging in cross-cultural medicine. We believe that international students not only belong in healthcare but are critical to the future of compassionate and culturally sensitive medical practice and the practice of cultural humility in healthcare settings.

The Harvard PRIMUS is concerned with the welfare and community representation of first-generation students at Harvard College. For the organization, a first-generation undergraduate student shall be defined as one whose parents or guardians have not completed a course of study at an accredited four-year undergraduate institution, or an equivalent and recognized qualification abroad. PRIMUS will seek to build more opportunities for learning for non-first-generation college students, in the belief that the broader Harvard community needs to understand the first-generation student experience. By communicating with non-first-generation students, PRIMUS will strive to dispel any stigma or stereotype associated with the first-generation identity.

The two aims of the Harvard Undergraduate Psychedelics Club: (I) Our first aim is to educate the general public about historical and current events in psychedelic spaces including research, policy, art, culture, and industry. (II) Our second aim is to create spaces for free expression and exchange of ideas, promoting discussion of psychedelics, psychedelia, and adjacent values and philosophies, including consciousness, art, and spirituality. We are not blindly encouraging the use of psychedelics; however, there is promising research on psychedelics in mental health treatment, and we celebrate the contribution of psychedelics in cultural spaces such as art and philosophy.

The purpose of Harvard Undergraduate Puzzle Club is to create an inclusive, active community for puzzle solving among Harvard students. HUPC aims to encourage collaboration among puzzle enthusiasts at the College.

The mission of the Harvard Undergraduate Quantitative Traders (HUQT) is to foster an educational and supportive community which, through mentorship and projects, prepares students for careers in quantitative finance. HUQT is comprised of many of Harvard’s brightest statistics, math, and computer science students. Our members are selected through a rigorous interview process and go on to intern and work full-time at the world’s leading quantitative hedge funds and market-makers, including Jane Street, Two Sigma, Citadel, HRT, Jump Trading, SIG, Optiver, IMC Trading, and more.

Our mission is to engage undergraduate students from any and all backgrounds in quantum computing. We aim to connect our members to faculty, researchers, and industry leaders from Harvard and beyond to help them learn more about quantum information and quantum computation, to expose them to research opportunities, and to build a diverse community of students exploring the quantum revolution.

Our mission is to advocate for the well-being of Queer students both on Harvard's campus and in the greater Massachusetts area as well as to educate students on Queer policy and teach them how to effectively narrate their stories to foster change.

At HUREIG, we are committed to maintaining our role as the premier space for real estate on Harvard University’s campus with our programs. Through The Development, we teach members the fundamentals of the real estate industry and how to valuate properties. The Investment Group, founded in 2022, gives more experienced members an opportunity to create investment and development pitches supported with quantitative and qualitative analysis. We welcome experts in the real estate field through our Speaker Series to visit us and speak to the members and non-members about their experiences in real estate. HUREIG collaborates closely with leaders in the global real estate industry-including industry experts, academics, and firms-to supplement the education offered at Harvard College.

Founded in 2007 upon the mission of building an interdisciplinary research community among undergraduates, our goal is to connect and expand the undergraduate research community every day. From conferences to mentorship to publishing, we are passionate about new opportunities for cutting-edge achievements.
