The Harvard Undergraduate Robotics Club (HURC) seeks to provide Harvard Undergraduates with an opportunity to participate in exciting and educational STEM-related projects, to engage students in machine-building processes, and to compete in a variety of robotics competitions. HURC seeks to encourage its members to always strive to create efficient and meaningful robots. Meetings will consist of robot and machine-building work sessions, programming work sessions, and engineering design discussions. HURC encourages its members to strive to create efficient and successful robots. HURC members will form teams and build robots in an effort to develop innovative solutions to problems. Meetings will consist of machine building, circuitry, and programming work sessions and,  engineering design discussions.
The goal of the HURA is to promote Romanian culture, tradition, and language within the scope of a global democratic multicultural society.

The mission of Harvard Undergraduate Rural League is twofold: 1) Provide a supportive and inclusive community for rural students at Harvard University to meet, share experiences, and foster connections. 2) Leverage the Harvard community’s talents and resources to assist rural communities by organizing and participating in initiatives that bridge the gap in access between rural and urban communities.

The Harvard Undergraduate Salon for the Sciences and Humanities is a forum to discuss the past, present, and future relationship between the sciences and humanities. Through group discussion and conversations with academics and professionals from various disciplines and of myriad opinions, members will critically and imaginatively assess the science-humanities relationship and determine how they can be integrated to address the greatest problems of the 21st century.

The mission of Science Club for Girls at Harvard College is to increase the self-confidence and science literacy of K–12th grade girls belonging to groups that are underrepresented in the sciences, through free after school programs that provide experiential learning, mentorship, and leadership opportunities. Girls work with mentor-scientists who model and foster leadership, affirm college as an expectation, and promote careers in science and technology as goals and options.  Science Club for Girls at Harvard College will work to create a community of Harvard undergraduate and graduate students dedicated to serving local Cambridge and Boston schools and generating enthusiasm for science through after school and extracurricular activities.  Science Club for Girls at Harvard College fulfills a need at Harvard College for a volunteering opportunity that empowers future women scientists, and it fulfills a need of the Cambridge community for free and educational after school opportunities.

The Harvard Undergraduate Science Olympiad (HUSO) is an undergraduate organization dedicated to enriching the experience of middle and high school students participating in science activities such as Science Olympiad. The national mission of Science Olympiad is as follows: "Science Olympiad is a national non-profit organization dedicated to improving the quality of K-12 science education, increasing male, female and minority interest in science, creating a technologically-literate workforce and providing recognition for outstanding achievement by both students and teachers. These goals are achieved by participating in Science Olympiad tournaments and non-competitive events, incorporating Science Olympiad into classroom curriculum and attending teacher training institutes."

The Harvard Undergraduate Scuba Club is dedicated to fostering a welcoming and safe community for all scuba diving enthusiasts at Harvard, from beginners to experienced divers. Our mission is to provide opportunities for students to engage in the sport, connect with fellow divers, and explore local and global diving sites.

Harvard Undergraduate Senior Stories is a student-run organization that connects students with residents at local aged-care centers, nursing homes, and elderly patients at rehabilitation centers to run creative writing workshops with residents.

Smart Woman Securities (SWS) seeks to provide undergraduate women with the skills necessary to make investment decisions through market education, exposure to industry professionals, and real-world financial experience, in an attempt to bridge the gender gap prevalent in the investment industry.

The mission of HUSSA is to create an inclusive space for Somali students at Harvard, promote understanding of Somali culture, and foster academic, social, and professional growth through community-building and support initiatives.

Given the unique political and cultural climate in South Africa, which is different to many other African countries, we wish to create a group specifically dedicated to this nation. This will provide a forum for South Africans and others interested in the country to discuss politics, network, listen to local music and celebrate South African traditions and holidays. We wish to celebrate our diverse culture, welcome freshmen, bid farewell to seniors and be a point of contact for anyone wanting to visit the country. We could also  be a bridge between the new Harvard office situated in Johannesburg and the undergraduate students currently at Harvard. Furthermore, we aim to be in touch with South African alumni network and faculty.

The South Asian Women’s Collective provides a cultural and social community for Harvard South Asian women and gender minorities and fosters meaningful discussions, new friendships, and a sense of belonging and comfort on campus. SAWC plans a mix of academic, social and cultural events that are open to all students.

The HSSS seeks to promote greater awareness and understanding of social, political, and cultural issues in the countries of the Former Yugoslavia (Bosnia and Herzegovina, Croatia, Macedonia, Serbia, Montenegro, and Slovenia) in the Harvard community by appropriate means such as publications, meetings, seminars and social events.
To unite and empower students of Spanish origin through cultural exchange, academic support, social gatherings, and the celebration of our heritage, fostering a vibrant community at Harvard.
Make sports fun for everyone, irrespective of ability!

The Harvard College Sports Analysis Collective (HSAC) is a student-run organization at Harvard College dedicated to the quantitative analysis of sports strategy and management. Founded in 2006, the club meets weekly and is for students interested in sports statistics, sports business, and problem solving.
HUSL combines sports with innovation, research, and collaboration creating a global hub that utilizes sports for catalytic change.

As the one of the youngest comedy groups on campus, HCSUCS has no stodgy old graduate board or years of tarnished history to fight against. This means we can and should always be at the forefront of inclusivity in the campus space. Stand up comedy is scary enough; we should do our absolute best to de-stress someone’s first time trying it! Everyone sucks the first time – you know that. There are many people who started standup in the club, or joined senior year, and are now incredible (Harrison Greenbaum didn’t do standup until college.)

The mission of the Harvard Undergraduate Surf Club is to connect undergraduates with a shared love for all things surfing. The club will host surf outings throughout the year for beginners and seasoned surfers alike, exploring the breaks that the east coast has to offer. We hope to create a community that is an exchange of surfing knowledge to improve as surfers and as people. Additionally, the Harvard Undergraduate Surf Club aims to work through education and action to protect our coastline and reduce ocean pollution.

The Harvard Undergraduate Survivor Club aims to build a community of students who are superfans of the television show Survivor. Our primary goal is to bring together fans from across campus to engage in social and recreational activities inspired by the show. By fostering a sense of camaraderie and mutual interest, we hope to enhance the college experience for all members through shared enjoyment and discussion.
Harvard Undergraduate Symphony Society is a Harvard student organization whose goal is to promote easy access for Harvard College students to great classical music by the Boston Symphony Orchestra.

Harvard Undergraduate Synapse Chapter is a student-run organization dedicated to combating the isolation individuals with brain injury often face through the creation of a powerful social support network.

TAMID Group facilitates experiential education and cultivates relationships to create a strong, lasting connection to Israel for emerging professionals. We focus on education through practice, with students participating in active consulting projects with startups and developing public equity research presentations with potential to deploy real capital.

Hello and welcome to the Harvard Undergraduate Tap Company (HUTC), Harvard's College's premier tap dance company! HUTC was founded in 1999 by two Harvard undergraduates who felt strongly that a tap dance company was the missing piece in Harvard's dance repertoire. Today, we carry on our founders' mission to bring the joy and power of tap dance to the Harvard community and beyond. We are an entirely student-run organization dedicated to telling dynamic stories through rhythm and sound. In addition to offering weekly company classes with both student and professional guest teachers, we perform at Harvard throughout the year and also guest perform at other tap shows in the Boston/Cambridge area. To get in touch and learn more, please email: harvardundergraduatetapcompany@gmail.com.
The Task Force for Asian American Progressive Advocacy and Studies (TAPAS) is a non-hierarchical progressive student group, advocating for ethnic studies at Harvard.

The Harvard Technology Review is a publication that explores the essentially human aspects of technology. HTR exists at the intersection between practice and theory, leveraging insight from both industry and academia. We aim to provide a community where undergraduates from interdisciplinary backgrounds can discuss the forefront of today’s tech scene and its societal implications.

- Community for students from Texas and the South - Low-commitment, welcoming, no comp, no fees - Not pre-professional, but connects students with top internships (BCG Austin) - Place to relax and escape what can feel like a superficial & exclusive social scene - Offer a positive perception of the South here in the northeast - Leverage our resources at Harvard to fuel progress in our communities

The mission of the Harvard Undergraduate Thai Society is as follows: 1. To cultivate the understanding of and interest in Thai culture and related issues in the general Harvard community. 2. To create community among students and scholars from Thailand, of Thai background, or have interests in Thai culture. 3. To promote contact with alumni around the world.

We are a student-run research collective that aims to bridge the gap between academia and advocacy. We want to use the vast and uniquely valuable academic resources at our disposal, including world-class professors, networks of experts, and highly-accomplished students to tackle some of the world’s most pressing issues. With that spirit in mind, we have chosen two research focuses in the realm of climate change and American leadership legitimacy through coordinated domestic and foreign policy.

At Harvard College, the Harvard Undergraduate Tibetan Cultural Association will allow for intellectual transformation, as Tibetans learn more about their identities and non-Tibetans draw parallels to their own experiences

The mission of Harvard Undergraduate Tuesday Magazine is to publish creative writing and art by Harvard University students and foster a literary and art community. The magazine is a vehicle through which both Harvard and non-Harvard communities can enjoy and study the creative work of Harvard students. Community events allow the community to bond and grow over a shared interest in literature, art, publishing, and the creative practice.

The Harvard Undergraduate Ukraine Solidarity Group (HUUSG) is a non-profit cultural organization that fosters a sense of community for both students of Ukrainian origin and individuals interested in Ukrainian culture and traditions.

The Harvard Undergraduate UNICEF Club, a student-run organization at Harvard College, is concerned with the humanitarian aid of children across the globe. Through various events and activities, we aim to support UNICEF in their goal to provide health care and immunizations, safe water and sanitation, nutrition, education, emergency relief, and more necessities to children.

Harvard Undergraduate United Nations Association is a public service and advocacy group concerned with engaging Harvard students interested in the United Nations and particularly its relations to the United States. Members will be involved in planning and hosting events related to the United Nations with the goal of improving their peers’ understanding of how the United States and the UN interact.

HUUSL is Harvard’s premier undergraduate urban studies and planning organization. We provide undergraduates with immediate ways to engage with urban issues, together imagining a more sustainable, livable, and equitable future for our cities through advocacy, research, and commentary.

The Harvard Undergraduate Venture Capital Group's core mission is to drive innovation by connecting founders and investors. We do so by offering our members the ability to identify promising founders, whose startups serve as successful investments for our Partner VCs

Harvard Undergraduate Ventures is concerned with demystifying and encouraging active, informed, and meaningful participation in startups and venture capital amongst Harvard students. By building a professional network and a community of undergraduates and alumni, Harvard Undergraduate Ventures provides students with skills, resources, and relationships to become leaders in the entrepreneurial ecosystem. We co-host the annual i3 Innovation Challenge to support student founders with cash grants. We also host workshops, fireside chats, socials, and networking events. Finally, we highlight student founders and various opportunities on our newsletter, on our social media, and on our podcast.

The Harvard Undergraduate Veritas Forum (‘Organization’) is concerned with asking and answering some of life’s hardest questions alongside fellow students, faculty, and experts. With a commitment to courageous discourse, this Organization puts the historic Christian faith in dialogue with other religious, ethical, and spiritual worldviews and invites participants from all backgrounds to confront difficult questions together. In doing so, this organization aims to create a space that seriously considers and lives out the original motto of Harvard University: “Veritas Christo et Ecclesiae,” in English “Truth for Christ and the Church.”

"Our mission is to provide comprehensive support to veterans at Harvard, fostering a welcoming community that encourages their academic and professional growth. We are committed to recognizing the unique needs and challenges facing veterans and to providing the resources and guidance necessary to help them succeed. Our organization offers a variety of services to support veterans, including mentorship opportunities, workshops, and training sessions that address topics such as academic and career development, financial planning, and mental health. We collaborate with other groups and organizations that serve veterans to provide additional resources and support. At our core, we believe that veterans bring valuable skills, experiences, and perspectives to our campus, and we are dedicated to creating a more inclusive and supportive environment that recognizes and celebrates their service and contributions. Through our efforts, we aim to empower veterans to reach their full potential, both academically and professionally, and to build a stronger, more diverse community that values and supports their unique experiences."

The mission of the Harvard Undergraduate Vision for All Initiative is to provide students with the opportunity to directly address issues of disparities in healthcare within the Boston community through the lens of ophthalmology.

The Harvard Whistler’s Society exists to bring undergraduates together across campus in pursuit of the art of whistling. We exist to provide a casual space for people interested in whistling with others, bring legitimacy and awareness to an atypical form of musical expression, and aid in the polishing of technical whistling chops.

Pliny the Elder’s wise words “In Vino Veritas” illustrate the belief that in wine there is truth. To illuminate another interpretation of the old Latin adage, the Harvard Undergraduate Wine Society was founded in 2011 with the philosophy of re-establishing the tradition of respecting and revering wine. We aim to promote social drinking in a responsible environment by cultivating an appreciation and understanding of wine, and to provide a common space for undergraduate students to meet and interact through the enjoyment of wine.

Harvard Undergraduate Women in Business (HUWIB) seeks to empower a dynamic group of enterprising young women, uniting them through business education and experience.  Serving the entire female Harvard undergraduate population, HUWIB is overseen by an Executive Board and eleven committees.

WICS is dedicated to building a community of technical women at Harvard and beyond. We believe every woman should have equal opportunity and encouragement to pursue computer science. We seek to empower women to consider careers in technology by providing education, mentorship, and role models for students at Harvard and in the greater Boston community. We strive to promote awareness of gender issues and to construct an environment for discussion and reform across universities and industries. We hope to create opportunities for individuals of all genders and interests to support these goals.

Harvard Undergraduate Women in Entrepreneurship (WE) is the foundational ecosystem for female student entrepreneurs at Harvard. By organizing in-person events, developing mentorship programs, and fostering a supportive network of students and alumni, Harvard WE connects innovators, thought leaders, and entrepreneurs. This vibrant community inspires and educates the next generation of female entrepreneurs.

Harvard Undergraduate Women in Foreign Policy (HUWiFP) is a student organization for female-identifying undergraduates looking to learn from and connect with peers and professionals in the fields of Foreign Policy, diplomacy, national Security, and intelligence. HUWIFP aims to empower young women in the exploration of foreign policy Career trajectories while fostering a sense of foreign policy community on campus.

The Women in Law Association (WiLA) strives to bridge the gap that exists for students with marginalized gender identities, including women, nonbinary, and femme individuals interested in pursuing law. Gender historically and continues to pose unique challenges for people navigating legal careers.

Harvard Undergraduate Women in Medicine is a strong community dedicated to empowering students to actively and critically engage in healthcare. Through our resources and programming, we strive to facilitate the advancement of equity in healthcare, promote awareness of gender issues, and spearhead action and service.

To create mentorship/support systems for pre-health and pre-clinical students, particularly those from diverse backgrounds and centered on human rights and medical progress; To offer professional/personal enrichment opportunities for pre-health  and pre-clinical students; To foster in-depth, progress-making conversations related to current health issues, with expert context and student views.
The guiding values of HUAF shall be institutional neutrality, nonviolent and respectful dialogue, academic freedom and free speech, and intellectual diversity.

HUBS is a team of Democrats, Republicans, and everything in between, working to facilitate open policy discussions and craft bipartisan solutions. We author real legislation, meet prominent political figures, and bridge campus and national divides.

Harvard Undergraduates for Inclusion in Economics (HUIE) believes in increasing diversity and inclusion in economics for people who belong to under-represented groups. The organization hopes to achieve this by creating mentorship opportunities, connecting students to faculty and staff, organizing events showcasing the diversity of post-graduation paths in economics, and fostering a stronger sense of community among students interested in economics.

The Harvard Undergraduates in Asia Program (HUAP), formerly the Harvard College in Asia Program (HCAP), is a platform for student exploration and development, connecting the world's future leaders and strengthening the international relationships of tomorrow.

HUNZ is concerned with creating a community for members of Harvard College to learn about and celebrate the culture and traditions of New Zealand. The organization will facilitate events of national significance, including Waitangi Day, ANZAC Day, and Matariki. HUNZ welcomes both New Zealanders and those with an interest in New Zealand to be part of our wh├ä┬ünau (family)!

At HURAA, we believe that advocacy is key to raising autism awareness and acceptance within the Harvard community. We organize events and campaigns that aim to educate people about autism and promote acceptance of neurodiversity. Our goal is to create a more inclusive and supportive environment for individuals with autism at Harvard and beyond.

Our mission is to advocate for youth justice. We aim to empower the young voices that can’t advocate for themselves. By influencing and shaping legislation and policy that promotes children’s mental health and upholds human rights, we aim to support and amplify the voices of young people, ensuring that policies reflect their unique needs and experiences. By working in both education and policy-based change, we strive to break down systemic barriers and create a more equitable society where all youth can thrive.Through research, advocacy, and community engagement, we seek to effect meaningful legislative reforms that prioritize the well-being and dignity of all young people.

The Harvard University Band (HUB) is a steadfast supporter of Harvard athletics at football, hockey, and basketball games, as well as performing at Commencement, special University functions, and charity events throughout the community. The Band's traditions, unique style, energy, and humor have represented and sustained Harvard's spirit for over 100 years.

The Harvard University Choir sings for the Sunday services and the annual Christmas Carol Services in The Memorial Church, and presents concerts of choral literature throughout the year. The sixteen Choral Fellows sing for the daily Morning Prayers service Mondays through Fridays during term. When the opportunity presents itself, the choir produces professional recordings and travels both domestically and abroad. The Harvard University Choir seeks to adhere to the highest professional standards of music-making, while fostering a profound sense of community amongst its members. Membership in this organization is open to all students and affiliates of Harvard University in good standing, regardless of race, creed, color, sex, gender identity, sexual orientation or physical disability. All officers of the choir shall be registered undergraduates in Harvard College.

Our Mission is to bring together Native American, Alaska Native, and Native Hawaiian students and interested individuals from the Harvard community for the purpose of advancing the well-being of Indigenous peoples through self-determination, academic achievement, and community service.
- To foster a community for Vietnamese people and allies on campus and promote Vietnamese culture

The Harvard Wind Ensemble is Harvard’s premier concert band committed to performing wind ensemble music of various genres for the Harvard community and beyond to audiences of various ages, cultures, abilities, etc. and providing a strong, close-knit community for all members.
to build a strong community, have great sportsmanship, and share our love of Lacrosse!

The purposes of this organization shall be: (1) to provide college and university students throughout the world with a conference that authentically simulates the workings of specified committees and specialized agencies of the United Nations; (2) to foster an understanding of the intricacies of international negotiation by encouraging active participation of students as United Nations delegates; (3) to provide Harvard students with an opportunity, which they may not have otherwise, to travel abroad and meet their peers from foreign nations and cultures in a common forum; (4) to promote a general awareness at Harvard of the growing importance of the United Nations as an arbiter of international conflicts; and (5) to distinguish Harvard as an institution concerned with educating the international community on the United Nations.

Harvard Yearbook Publications is an entirely student-run nonprofit organization. Our mission is to preserve the memories of each Harvard class by creating an accurate and authentic record of their life at Harvard College. We do this by publishing the Yearbook for the graduating senior class and the Register for the incoming first-years each year, and by showcasing our Photo Board's exceptional photography through the sale of photo prints.

AAA strives to unite Asian American students at Harvard and raise greater awareness of Asian American issues through social, cultural, and political events. We aim to: Foster a community within Harvard dedicated to embracing our shared identity and promoting greater awareness of Asian American issues and perspectives; Provide a forum for Asian Americans at Harvard to voice their opinions and comfortably explore their culture, identity, and individuality; Address political, economic, and social issues affecting our communities at Harvard as well as at the local and national levels; Celebrate achievements of Asian Americans, including those in the arts, entertainment, politics, business, science, and academia; Develop long-lasting partnerships between students, alumni, community activists, and scholars; Inspire participants to contemplate their roles and responsibilities in forging the future of Asian America.
We are a fellowship that seeks to know God and make God known as a voice of faith, particularly among the Asian and Asian-American community at Harvard.

The Asian American Women’s Association (AAWA) recognizes the need for a supportive, vocal community for Asian American women at Harvard. AAWA strives to address these needs through open and accessible dialogue and inclusive community-building events. By generating discussion about and spreading awareness of issues that pertain to the varied experiences of the members of our community, AAWA seeks to promote and celebrate the joy, prominence, and concerns of people who can identify with the experiences of Asian American womenhood in a way that is accessible and pertinent to the greater Harvard community

The purpose of the Harvard-Radcliffe Chinese Students Association is to promote awareness of Chinese culture and society while supporting a social environment for students of all backgrounds at Harvard College. HRCSA will not discriminate against any potential members on the basis of race, color, religion, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity, national or ethnic origin, age, disability, or other factors irrelevant to participation in programs of the College. HRCSA does not participate in hazing activities.

We, the Harvard-Radcliffe Collegium Musicum, strive to advance the choral art through dynamic performances of both classical masterpieces and innovative new works; foster a passionate community of student musicians; and spread a love for music through collaborative endeavors, tours, and community engagement.

The purpose of the HRDC shall be to promote interest in student theater at Harvard College, to organize and administer student participation in the Loeb Drama Center, to produce plays on the Loeb Proscenium and Loeb Experimental Theater, and to act as an umbrella organization for Harvard student theater by encouraging and assisting in the production of plays elsewhere on campus.

The Harvard-Radcliffe Gilbert & Sullivan Players (HRG&SP) is an independent, nonprofit, student-run theatrical organization at Harvard College dedicated to performing the work of William Schwenck Gilbert and Sir Arthur Sullivan. HRG&SP presents one production each semester in Radcliffe's historic Agassiz Theatre, fosters community among its participants, and seeks to promote appreciation and awareness of the works of Gilbert & Sullivan in the greater Harvard and Boston communities.

Established in 1976, The Harvard-Radcliffe Modern Dance Company (HRMDC) is the oldest dance organization at Harvard College. We are a contemporary dance group that welcomes a wide variety of dance styles, and we are dedicated to creating and supporting innovative student choreography and performance. HRMDC offers members weekly company classes, guest workshops, and the opportunity to perform and choreograph in the company's biannual shows.

The Mozart Society Orchestra (MSO), founded in 1984, is Harvard’s premier classical-sized orchestra, enjoying both the intimate music-making of a chamber orchestra and the power of masterpieces usually performed by symphony orchestras. Though musical excellence is its top concern, MSO also boasts one of the most friendly and collegial atmospheres among the musical ensembles on campus.

We are a social club. There is nowhere else at Harvard that you'll find so many people who share your interests in speculative fiction, be it fantasy, science fiction, or otherwise, and gaming. We talk about these things. We play board games together. We sponsor guest speakers; in the past, we've had Joe Haldeman, Terry Pratchett, and Catherine Asaro. We have a library with more than 3000 books, and more board games than we have yet been able to count. Whatever nerdy experience you want, HRSFA can provide.

We advocate for and advance the interests of our members both within the Physics Department and the broader academic community. Our mission is to maintain an active and recognized chapter that not only meets the standards of the National Society of Physics Students through the submission of annual reports and maintaining good standing but also engages actively with the student body through representation at university events, conferences, and activity fairs. We endeavor to foster a collaborative and supportive environment for our members by managing seven undergraduate committees. We work closely with the Physics Department's leadership to ensure that our plans and initiatives align with academic standards and contribute positively to our members' educational experience.

The Veritones are a co-ed organization dedicated to the performance and appreciation of a cappella music for mixed voices and to the fostering of that appreciation among the College student body and the general public.
To create space, visibility, and community for Mexican students at Harvard University since 1972.

The Hasty Pudding Institute of 1770’s philanthropic mission is to provide educational and developmental support in all aspects of the performing arts for the underprivileged, to encourage satire and comedy, and to cultivate young talent around the world.

HealthPath Horizons at Harvard is committed to addressing the critical disparities that prevent students from underserved and underrepresented backgrounds from accessing opportunities in the healthcare field. Many students from lower-income communities face significant challenges when exploring medical careers, such as limited access to shadowing opportunities, professional mentorship, and resources for navigating the medical school application process.
To makes other laugh through the best form of performative comedy: improv.
Indigo Magazine is a literary arts magazine that is dedicated to creating a home for Black art of campus.

Peer counseling is a service for Harvard undergrads to use when they need to need process concerns or experiences to another person, and it’s in a confidential setting. Indigo strives to foster a supportive and compassionate campus for undergraduate students grappling with and addressing issues of race, ethnicity, socioeconomic status, first generation, immigration status, and other identity concerns at Harvard College. Indigo provides confidential non-directive, non-judgmental, peer counseling as well as informational resources for students. We seek to support students of all racial and socioeconomic backgrounds and help create an open and welcoming campus climate based on respect of all students.

Established as a memorial to President Kennedy, the IOP’s mission is to unite and engage students, particularly undergraduates, with academics, politicians, activists, and policymakers on a non-partisan basis to inspire them to consider careers in politics and public service. Through our sixteen programs, internships, and conferences, the IOP offers wide-ranging opportunities for students to practice, get inspired, and gain the skills for a future in public service.

Camp Kesem Harvard Undergraduate is committed to creating a world where every child who has a parent with a cancer diagnosis or has lost a parent to cancer is never alone. We support these children through and beyond their parent's cancer by offering free, fun-filled summer camp and year-round programming.

KDSAP has two key objectives: student career development and community outreach. KDSAP is a student-run organization targeting college students and aims to provide opportunities for community outreach to raise public awareness and promote early detection of chronic kidney disease (CKD). In addition, KDSAP offers many innovative programs to benefit its student members, including speaker series each semester that expose students to scientific and medical professions while facilitating the development of mentor-mentee relationships. Members may also participate in community outreach and develop leadership skills by organizing, managing, and running monthly kidney health screenings in medically underserved communities.

Latinas Unidas shall be the materialization of a vision: the unification of Harvard College students who have a passion for and/or interest in the lives of Latina women. LU provides a forum for community building, intellectual discussion, and the empowerment of women. We believe that our individual backgrounds, while diverse, combine to form a strong and unique culture. We foster this strength and unity through three main branches of action: 1) Advocacy Events 2) Social Events and 3) Professional Outreach. We believe and embrace the important responsibility to the Latinx and greater Latin American community to showcase the power of women, build communal ties, and establish long-lasting career pipelines.
Our mission is to provide a place on the Harvard Campus for any maker to innovate and create any project they want to create but need some guidance or teamwork in helping to create.

The mission of the Harvard MEDLIFE Club is to support global health equity by partnering with underserved communities to provide access to high-quality healthcare, education, and safe development projects. We empower students to become socially conscious leaders through hands-on service, health education, and advocacy. By working both locally in Boston and internationally through Service Learning Trips, we strive to address the root causes of poverty and promote long-term, sustainable change.

Our mission is to create social, intellectual, and cultural activities for both Indigenous/Native students at Harvard and for other interested members of the Harvard community. We recognize that Indigenous/Native students are an ultra-minority and attempt to foster a sense of community among our members. We also try to educate the Harvard community about Indigenous/Native issues and debunk popular misconceptions of Indigenous/Native individuals through our activities and events.

The Noteables shall be dedicated to the singing and performing of songs from musical theatre and musical cinema. Moreover, it shall be a group that provides an opportunity for undergraduates who love to sing to pursue that interest in a non-competitive atmosphere.

The mission of Omo Naija x The Wahala Boys is to educate the members of the greater Harvard community through dance and its role in the culture of the Afro-Caribbean. While dance is not generally imagined when one imagines education, the arts have historically served as some of the best cultural and educational tools available. While Omo Naija is close-knit, it is also a space for members of the African Diaspora across campus to find cultural roots, and to take part in the making and spreading of something amazing. Many on this campus know very little about Afro-Caribbean dance and culture and thus while we love that this organization is a fun way to express ourselves, it also serves as a community with which the Harvard community can engage, participate, and learn.
OTI commits to performing improv comedy at least once a month, free of charge and on Harvard’s campus.

First and foremost, OAASIS presents its members — regardless of how they identify along race, nationality, religion, ethnicity, gender, class, and orientation —with a community that engages with the diverse experiences of Asians and Asian Americans. ​OAASIS serves its members through shaping strong and confident leaders who take ownership of their identity to move through the world in an empowered way. Members of OAASIS are committed to creating a space for mutual growth and empowerment by serving fellow members and the organization.​
To build community for Orthodox Christian students on campus

The Orthodox Student Minyan (OSM) is a social and religious group of Orthodox Jewish undergraduates at Harvard College. We host prayer and learning events, foster a culture of love of Torah and mitzvot, and build community around Jewish values.

The Mission Hill After School Program (MHASP) aims to provide a safe, fun, and positive learning experience for children in the Mission Hill community.  Through personalized attention, creative lesson planning, and involvement from the community, the Mission Hill After School Program seeks to provide the most full and rewarding experience for all of its participants.

Founded in 1985, PBHA’s CHANCE (College High-school Alliance: A Nexus for Creative Education) is a college preparatory program which strives to give students from local high schools the desire, support, and motivation to gain admission to college and to succeed there and beyond. CHANCE provides SAT tutoring, homework help, and college application advising to students in grades 9-12.Thanks to the F. Gardner Jackson Fund, CHANCE is able to award scholarships to students from local high schools. All who have regularly attended CHANCE and are in their junior or senior year are eligible.

Chinatown Big Sib is a one-to-one mentorship program run by Harvard College students with the Phillips Brooks House Association. The program offers young children ages 6 to 12 years from the Boston Chinatown neighborhood a unique experience with getting to know and spending time with college students from the area. Our college student volunteers, or “Big Sibs”, are responsible for organizing one-on-one outings with their “Little Sibs” every other weekend. With these meetings and interactions, the program strives to build a strong relationship between Sib pairings. Big Sibs may take on the role of a mentor in academic, social, emotional context, or simply whatever best provides for their Little Sibs. This program runs full year, where Sib pairings remain the same throughout both semesters unless other arrangements are made.

ExperiMentors is committed to addressing the critical need for accessible STEM education and inspiring the next generation of scientists, scholars, and innovators. Together, we strive to empower elementary school students in Cambridge to explore science through hands-on, curiosity-driven learning beyond the limitations of traditional textbooks. Additionally, ExperiMentors aims to foster a lasting network of volunteers, teachers, and students, united by a shared passion for scientific learning. Through meaningful collaboration, we cultivate a space where learning thrives, curiosity is celebrated, and young minds are excited to question, explore, and lead.

The Harvard Square Homeless Shelter provides roughly 15-20 homeless individuals at a time with a safe, clean, and caring place to stay during the winter months. In addition to temporary shelter, HSHS also provides counseling resources and a transitional program for guests who are employed and committed to saving money towards securing housing.

To empower elementary school girls through providing information on strong female role models, guidance on how mentees can pursue their dreams, and support for their personal goals, unique personalities, and paths.

PBHA’s Student Labor Action Movement (SLAM) is committed to activism and education in support of social and economic justice. Made up of Harvard students, workers, and activists, SLAM organizes in support of workers’ rights and a more equitable Harvard community. SLAM campaigns have been directed toward worker and labor issues on campus and on a national level; they include the Living Wage Campaign and the Ethical Investments and Contracting, as well as campaigns initiated by local unions and community organizations. SLAM members participate in and help lead campaigns, as well as organize new ones.

The Harvard Undergraduate Legal Committee (HULC) gets students excited about legal aid, public interest law, and public service through volunteering with pro bono organizations throughout the Greater Boston Area and consistent programming that educates members on the pathways to and impact of legal advocacy.

Y2Y Harvard Square (Y2Y), a student-run overnight shelter, employs a youth-to-youth model to provide a safe and affirming environment for young adults experiencing homelessness. Y2Y guests will have opportunities to collaborate with service providers, other young adults experiencing homelessness, and student volunteers to create sustainable pathways out of homelessness and develop skills for long-term success. Y2Y provides opportunities for both guests and volunteers to become the next generation’s leading advocates for young adult-driven solutions to homelessness.

PBHA strives for social justice. As a student-led organization, PBHA mobilizes volunteers in collaboration with Boston and Cambridge partners to address gaps in opportunities and resources. We develop student and community leadership to creatively meet critical needs and advocate for structural change. PBHA seeks to promote social awareness and community involvement at Harvard and beyond.

The Radcliffe Choral Society Foundation preserves and advances treble, soprano-alto, and women’s choral music as a vital part of the musical canon, empowers singers to lead rich and creative lives, and connects  generations of singers with one another in pursuit of artistic excellence and in service to the  broader community, and advances gender equity within music, higher education, and beyond.
Empower communities with programs that improve their members’ health, education, and capacity for personal and professional development

Our organization aims to provide support and community to Sikhs at Harvard by engaging in advocacy, planning events, sponsoring trips to gurdwara, and doing mentorship work here and in the general Boston area.

Founded in 2012, Sexual Education by Harvard College Students (SEHCS) is a student organization dedicated to empowering members of the Harvard community to explore their experiences with love and sex by providing comprehensive sexual education programming on Harvard’s campus. ​ During SEHCS' annual Sex Week (in the fall) and Sex Weekend (in the spring),  we invite local sex educators to campus to lead interdisciplinary, scholastic, and highly engaging workshops. At the end of each event, SEHCS distributes safe sex supplies and sex toys to attendees, courtesy of our generous sponsors.
To provide a network and community for Singaporeans, Indonesians and Malaysians, and anyone connected to these countries, on campus.

The mission of SHAM is to promote the enjoyment, study, and performance of magic. SHAM strives to create a community centered around the appreciation of this unique art form. SHAM is concerned with using the art of magic in performance and practice to  encourage mental transformation across the College community.
Provide an open community for South Asian Men and others to celebrate cultures, build community, and provide mentorship.
The mission of SAMA is to cultivate a love for South Asian music and its rich diversity through practice, performance, and community.

STRIVE provides an opportunity for fun and recluse from the busy student life on Saturdays and accrue volunteer hours without even realizing it. STRIVE, under the larger non-profit organization NextStep,  is a program designed to connect Harvard mentors with  youth with sickle-cell anemia from Boston area middle and high schools.

STAHR is focused on providing students the opportunity to learn about and engage in recreational astronomy. STAHR also seeks to promote interest in science and foster a healthy, inclusive community centered around our common interests. STAHR provides students with education in recreational astronomy with its Telescope Training Classes at the Loomis-Michael Observatory. Students who successfully complete the semester-long class receive HUID card access to the Loomis-Michael Observatory for the remainder of their degree program at Harvard University. STAHR is committed to offering advanced instruction in observational astronomy subjects, including, but not limited to astrophotography, to further students’ knowledge in the field. STAHR is committed to holding community events, including its semesterly dark sky trips, open house observatory nights, and movie nights. In addition, STAHR is committed to helping the student community learn about opportunities in astronomy through initiatives including, but not limited to, speaking engagements with professionals in the sciences.

“Tempus: The Harvard College History Review is the undergraduate journal of the Harvard History Department. The journal was founded by Adam G. Beaver and Sujit M. Raman in 1998 to publish original historical scholarship by undergraduates. In the spring of 2009, Tempus transitioned to an online format. After a brief return to print from the spring of 2013 to the spring of 2019, and a second digital stint during the COVID-19 pandemic, Tempus is now a hybrid publication with both digital and print issues. Any Harvard undergraduate can submit a history paper to the Editorial Staff for consideration for the Journal; most submissions are papers first prepared for Harvard classes. Works in the Forum and Profiles are authored by Tempus editors. To submit a paper, please email the Editorial Staff at tempus.thchr@gmail.com. Additional information and past issues may be found online at www.tempusharvard.org. This issue is printed with the generosity of the Harvard University Department of History.”

We, the members of The Cuban-American Undergraduate Student Association (CAUSA) at Harvard University, establish this constitution in recognition of the heritage of Cuba, with a special focus on Afro-Cuban and Indigenous Cuban identities, and with a commitment to building community and sustaining engagement among Cuban and Cuban-American undergraduate students. Inspired by principles of unity, inclusivity, and mutual respect, we pledge to create a supportive environment where members can explore, celebrate, and advocate for the diverse experiences and perspectives within the Cuban identity. With a dedication to promoting awareness, dialogue, and collaboration, we uphold the value of contributing positively to our community, university, and beyond. In witness whereof, we affirm this constitution to guide our actions and aspirations as members of CAUSA, committed to the advancement of our shared mission and the empowerment of all who join us on this journey.
The Fleur-de-Lis Club (or FDL Club) serves as an open and inclusive social space on campus.

Reach. Grow. Together. The Franklin Fellowship is one of the strongest communities at Harvard. Members are willing to drop anything to support one another in times of need, and in times of celebration. Friendship and adventure frequently craft some of our members’ favorite memories from Harvard.

The Harvard Advocate is concerned with supporting literature and the Arts on campus. The organization shall accomplish this by publishing an eponymous literary magazine, holding readings, putting on art shows, holding literary contests, providing a forum for social interaction among students interested in the Arts, and other literary and artistic events.

The Harvard Callbacks is an independent, nonprofit, student-run, and student-produced singing group at Harvard College. The Callbacks are dedicated to enriching both the musical and performing arts communities of Harvard University through original arrangements and live performance. The group seeks to foster a vibrant musical atmosphere at Harvard by offering both free and paid performances on campus, as well as participating in community-oriented music events.

The Harvard Crimson is the only breakfast-table daily newspaper in Cambridge, Mass. The Crimson publishes every morning, Monday through Friday, except on federal and University holidays, and prints weekly on Fridays. The Crimson publishes an Arts section on Tuesdays. Fifteen Minutes, the magazine of The Crimson, publishes weekly online and prints a monthly glossy edition.
The Din & Tonics exists to perform a cappella music of varying style and origin, with emphasis on jazz standards and the Great American Songbook, for audiences around the world.

As part of the Office of Culture and Community, the Harvard Foundation will continue to serve the entire Harvard College community by ensuring that each student is treated with equal dignity and respect.

The mission of The Harvard Krokodiloes (hereafter “Krokodiloes”) is to spread the joy and the value of its music in the hopes of enriching the audiences’ and the members’ lives through the powers of human sharing. As Harvard’s oldest a cappella singing group, the Krokodiloes are a versatile group of twelve tuxedo-clad undergraduates who sing jazz, swing, ballads, and rock music from the 20th century and beyond to audiences all over the world. Apart from the numerous performances at Harvard’s campus and in and around the Greater Boston Area, the Krokodiloes every year embark on a Winter Tour to North American destinations, a Spring Tour to Bermuda, and a flagship Summer World Tour that advance the TTBB-identified mission of the group onto the global scene.

The Harvard Salient fights to restore Harvard's traditions of free speech, intellectual rigor, and open debate. Through our publication, campus headquarters, and sponsored events, The Harvard Salient builds a powerful community of conservative students, alumni, and faculty who combat the ideological uniformity of Harvard University’s campus.

We're THUD (The Harvard Undergraduate Drummers), a student-run organization at Harvard College that likes to get together on Sundays afternoons Monday evenings and hit things. We play everything with percussive potential: drum set battles, arrangements of pop and classical music, original pieces on found instruments like plastic cups and chalkboards, drumming on buckets, and more. Inspirations include STOMP and the Blue Man Group. We perform around Harvard Square when it's nice out and are available for gigs in the Cambridge and Boston area. Our work culminates at the end of each semester with our shows.

The Harvard Ichthus is a journal of Christian thought.  It exists for the purpose of fostering deep Christian thought among the members of the Harvard community, taking seriously the motto of Harvard University: “Veritas Christo et Ecclesiae,” in English “Truth for Christ and the Church.”  It adopts these words of the Rev. Prof. Peter J. Gomes, preached at the Memorial Church, as its mission statement: "There is a rumor about, and fanned in certain quarters, that this University has long since abandoned its ancient motto and is conformable only to ‘Veritas.’  That simply is not true.  The seal by which the President and Fellows of Harvard College continue to conduct their business is still the seal that says: ‘Veritas Christo et Ecclesiae.’  One cannot undo the past, and in this particular case one should not undo the past. The university-- and this University in particular-- is in the business of goodness and virtue personified, and not simply in the bottom lines of fairness and excellence. Christ and the Church were an essential part of that truth to which Harvard and the generations of its children were committed.  ...Truth for Christ and the Church is not here by accident or by sufferance; it is here by design and intent.  ...Indeed, as a symbol of Christian truth, we are here to remind Harvard of a dimension beyond its own self-interest and self-perception... We Christians must never forget, nor must we permit our College or our University ever to forget, that knowledge without virtue is a destructive danger that produces arrogant technocrats who are a danger to all that is holy, hopeful, lovely, and true, and who must be resisted.  Our pious ancestors understood this, and thus they dedicated this small, fragile College in the wilderness to a truth that was seen in and for Christ and the Church.  Veritas-- that is, true Veritas, and not simply correct information-- can never be separated from the one in whom it is most perfectly and fully seen: Jesus Christ.  Not everyone may believe that, but those of us who do must not be intimidated by those who don't, and we must be emboldened to claim that truth not only as our own but as one that is essential to the definition of a University and College worthy of the name." (Strength for the Journey, pgs. 56, 60)

Founded in 2007, The Harvard Undergraduate Research Journal (THURJ) strives to publicize and spread recognition of original work by undergraduates in Harvard's undergraduate programs. THURJ serves as an ambassador of Harvard's undergraduate research activities at a university more known for its graduate programs. THURJ showcases peer-reviewed undergraduate student research from all research disciplines, including the natural sciences, the social sciences, and the humanities. A biannual publication, THURJ gives students an opportunity to be involved with the entire research publication process, beginning with manuscript submission and evaluation, ranging through design and ending with dissemination of results. Moreover, THURJ provides a comprehensive forum for discourse on the cutting-edge research that impacts our world today.

The Harvard College Jazz Bands strive to promote awareness and appreciation of instrumental jazz at Harvard through annual performances of classic music of master composers as well as contemporary pieces, hosting of guest artists, and commissioning of new works. In pursuit of this goal, the Jazz Bands host fall and spring concerts featuring guest artists spanning the history of jazz, as well as other concerts throughout the year.

The purpose of The Ivy is the promotion of growth in character, of unity of feeling, of affection and of social communion among its members. Being a part of our community gives us all a unique tie and bonds us in a commitment to support one another.
Harvard's premier organization for the reinvention of man.
The mission of the Kuumba Singers of Harvard College is to express the creativity and spirituality of Black people through song.

The Pitches were founded 48+ years ago with the mission of breaking down barriers and democratizing access to opportunities for women in the arts at Harvard, whose voices had long been marginalized. Now, we are an inclusive space for all genders to come together an celebrate our shared love of jazz a cappella.

The River Charles Ensemble, Harvard’s premier conductor-less chamber orchestra, is dedicated to the highest quality of music-making and performance. Formed in the spring of 2012, the River Charles Ensemble is a community of musicians who believe in the power and application of chamber music techniques to solo and orchestral performances. Using a democratic and collective approach, the orchestra is dedicated to working with student musicians of all kinds and strongly believes in musical collaborations all across the Harvard community. The musicians of the River Charles Ensemble share a passion for this distinctive and innovative approach to music.
Women's Empowerment & Community

The Wellness Educators (WEs) are the undergraduate peer education arm of CWHP. WEs work alongside the CWHP to engage the Harvard College community in health promotion and cultivate all aspects of student health and wellbeing (physical, relational, emotional, financial, spiritual, environmental, intellectual, and vocational). WEs connect our community to health resources, wellness information and practices, and promote holistic wellbeing for all students.

TLA is a joke-cracking, fun-loving, second family. We perform monthly improv shows on campus, travel to and host troupes from other schools and hold an annual events. TLA is grounded in joy, tradition, and more than anything, inclusivity, striving to create a safe, non-judgmental space for students to practice and enjoy comedy on campus.

The mission of Transgender Undergraduates of Harvard is to foster an environment where trans+ undergraduates of all backgrounds not only survive, but thrive – academically, socially, and personally. We envision a Harvard that offers robust trans+ resources, programming, and community. We envision a world that supports and affirms trans+ identities.

Founded in 2001, the Undergraduate Mariachi Véritas is Harvard’s one and only mariachi. We strive to create spaces to learn about and showcase Mexican culture through traditional music, while also presenting members from all communities a chance to perform it. Through a dedication to musical excellence and our core values, each member will not only add to our rich and diverse history, but will help foster a stronger, more united community both on campus and in the greater Boston community. Through this process, we will help foster a strong, united, and supportive ensemble.

The Winthrop House Committee is a student-led organization focused on creating welcoming and inclusive spaces at Winthrop House through community events, projects, and additional house-wide initiatives.

The Woodbridge Society aims to support international college students and foster the international community. The Society aims to provide a social and intellectual forum for individuals from all over the world, educate members of the Harvard College community on issues of international importance, build a global network among students of the College, and foster a spirit of global awareness and cultural exchange. The Society advocates for the international community by maintaining strong relationships with the relevant Harvard offices, connecting students to resources, and organizing events.
